questions.text: A 45-y/o female presents with symptomatic gallstones and is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the surgeon encounters difficulty due to unexpected anatomical variations. The right hepatic artery appears very tortuous and is located close to the cystic duct. What is the most likely anatomical anomaly encountered in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moynihan Hump

Explanation:

  • Moynihan's hump, also known as the 'caterpillar turn,' describes a very tortuous common or right hepatic artery in front of the cystic duct's origin. This tortuosity often results in a short cystic artery, increasing the risk of arterial injury during cholecystectomy.
  • It is the most dangerous anomaly to be encountered during laparoscopic cholecystectomy as it can lead to heavy bleeding due to injury to the arteries.

Phrygian cap (Option A) is a congenital variant of the gallbladder characterized by a fold at the fundus that resembles a cap. It is a benign condition and is typically asymptomatic, with its appearance being consistent with a cap-like structure on ultrasound. It has no clinical significance and does not affect gallbladder function.

 

Floating gallbladder (Option C) refers to an abnormal positioning of the gallbladder within the abdominal cavity, often due to a lack of supporting attachments. This condition does not present as a cap-like fold on ultrasound.

 

Mirizzi syndrome (Option D) occurs when a gallstone migrates from the gallbladder and obstructs or compresses the common bile duct, often due to a stone in the lower end of the cystic duct ulcerating into the common bile duct.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman at 41 weeks gestation comes to the labour and delivery room. On per vaginal examination, her BISHOP score is 9 and uterine contractions every 30 min. Artificial rupture of membranes is planned using the instrument shown in the image below. Which of the following is the instrument being used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kocher's forceps

 

Explanation:

  • The patient is undergoing surgical augmentation of labor.

  • Identified by toothed tips: one side has one tooth, the other has two.

  • Designed to grasp fetal membranes.

  • Available in straight or curved forms.

  • Kocher's Forceps have Multiple uses in Obstetrics:

    • Clamping Umbilical Cord
    • Artificial Rupture of Membranes
    • Hemostatic and Pedicle Clamp

 

Allis forceps (Option A): Typically used to grasp tissue like skin or fascia, not suitable for artificial rupture of menbranes 

Simpson forceps (Option B) : 

  • Obstetrical forceps assist in delivering the fetal head during childbirth.

  • Not used for artificial rupture of membranes

Kielland forceps (Option C)​​​​​​: Rotational forceps are used to rotate and deliver the fetal head in assisted vaginal delivery.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with a family history of glaucoma presents with mild visual disturbances. Her intraocular pressure is measured to be 24 mmHg in both eyes. On dilated fundus examination, the following findings are noted:


	The cup-to-disc ratio of 0.5
	Splinter hemorrhages at the optic disc margin
	Wedge-shaped retinal nerve fiber layer defects on red-free light examination


What stage of glaucomatous optic disc changes is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Early glaucomatous changes

 

Explanation:

  • Early glaucomatous changes are indicated by signs such as:
    • Cup-to-disc ratio of >0.3.
    • Asymmetry of the cups: A cup-to-disc ratio difference greater than 0.2 between two eyes.
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin.
    • Retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) defects: Wedge-shaped dark areas seen on the red-free light examination - an early indicator of glaucomatous damage.
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes
    • Cup-to-disc ratio of 0.7–0.9
    • Significant neuroretinal rim thinning
    • Vessel bayonetting
  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy
    • Complete destruction of the neural tissue
    • Deeply excavated and white optic disc.
    • Cavernous optic atrophy - large caverns or lacunae are formed due to:
      • Raised IOP leading to modulation of lamina cribrosa.
      • Ischaemic atrophy of the nerve fibers without a corresponding increase of supporting glial tissue.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane. The image is given below. What type of perforation is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Attic

 

Explanation:

The image shows perforation in the pars flaccida - attic perforation

  • The attic and posterosuperior marginal perforation are seen in dangerous types of CSOM and are often associated with a cholesteatoma. Stratified squamous epithelium from the external auditory canal can grow into the middle ear in any type of marginal perforation by immigration and form a cholesteatoma. Therefore, all marginal perforations are considered dangerous.
  • Central perforations are considered safe as cholesteatomas are usually not associated with them. It is seen in tubotympanic CSOM.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral cataracts, short stature, premature greying and loss of hair, and skin changes. He also reports joint stiffness and pain, as well as type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, the patient appears older than his stated age, with characteristic "bird-like" facies and a high-pitched voice. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with his presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Werner syndrome

Explanation:

The clinical presentation points towards Werner syndrome, also known as Adult Progeria Syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by premature ageing features that typically manifest in adulthood. It is associated with a DNA helicase defect.

Hutchinson-Gilford Syndrome (Option A): It is a rare genetic progeroid syndrome characterized by severe premature ageing features that begin in childhood. It is a Laminopathy due to a Lamin-A (LMNA) gene mutation.

Wermer Syndrome (Option C): Wermer Syndrome is for as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1).

Cockayne Syndrome (Option D): It is also a rare autosomal recessive progeroid syndrome. However, it typically presents in childhood. ERCC gene defect.

questions.text: Identify the disease associated with the image provided:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gaucher's disease:

  • The given image shows a crumpled tissue paper appearance of a macrophage which is a characteristic finding of Gaucher’s disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not show crumpled tissue appearance.

questions.text: A 45 y/o patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia. Lab tests reveal a low urine osmolarity and a high plasma osmolarity. After administration of desmopressin (a synthetic analog of ADH), the patient's urine osmolarity increases significantly. Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which ADH improved the patient's condition?

choices.text: ADH increases the permeability of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle to water.
ADH decreases the active transport of sodium chloride in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water.
ADH causes the osmolarity of the medullary interstitium to decrease rapidly.

questions.solution:
ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water by promoting the insertion of aquaporin-2 water channels into the apical membranes of collecting duct cells. This allows water to be reabsorbed from the tubular fluid into the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium, concentrating the urine and reducing urine volume.

A) The ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water, a characteristic that is essential for the creation of a hyperosmotic medullary interstitium. ADH does not alter this permeability.

B)ADH does not affect the active transport of sodium chloride in the thick ascending limb. The active transport in this segment is necessary for establishing the osmotic gradient but is not regulated by desmopressin.

D)ADH does not decrease the osmolarity of the medullary interstitium. Instead, it facilitates water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, leveraging the existing high osmolarity of the medullary interstitium to concentrate the urine.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and high myopia undergoes cataract surgery. During the procedure, she suddenly experiences severe ocular pain and a rapid rise in intraocular pressure. Fundoscopic examination reveals a dark red elevation in the choroidal region. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step?

choices.text: Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber
Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage
Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests suprachoroidal hemorrhage. The immediate steps involve closing the wound to prevent further prolapse of intraocular contents and monitoring intraocular pressure.

 

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage:

  • A suprachoroidal haemorrhage involves a bleed into the suprachoroidal space from a ruptured short posterior ciliary artery.
  • If suciently severe, it may result in extrusion of intraocular contents (expulsive haemorrhage).
  • It is a dreaded complication, but extremely rare (0.04%) with phacoemulsication.
  • Signs:
    • Progressive shallowing of the AC, increased IOP, and iris prolapse.
    • Vitreous extrusion, loss or partial obscuration of the red reflex and the appearance of a dark mound behind the pupil.
    • In severe cases, posterior segment contents may be extruded into the AC and through the incision.
  • Management:

Immediate

Subsequate
  • Closure of the incision with a suture to retain residual viscoelastic in the eye.
  • Diagnosis should be confirmed at the slit-lamp as soon as possible.
  • Acetazolamide to lower intraocular pressure.
  • Intensive topical and systemic steroids to reduce inflammation, with standard postoperative antibiotic treatment and IOP management.
  • Drainage, if subsequent hemorrhage fails to resolve (after 7-14 days, by which liquefaction of blood clot has taken place).
  • Pars plana vitrectomy may be considered when the retina appears adherent or detached.


Intraoperative posterior sclerostomy (Option A) should not be performed during the management of suprachoroidal hemorrhage because it increases the risk of complications such as infection and retinal detachment. The immediate focus should be on stabilizing the eye by controlling intraocular pressure and closing the incision. Once stabilized, further surgical interventions can be evaluated in a safer environment.

 

Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber (Option B): Increasing infusion pressure may worsen the bleeding.

 

Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage (Option C): Immediate vitrectomy is generally avoided initially as it could exacerbate the hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents with severe breathlessness, palpitations, and swelling in her legs and face. She primarily eats white rice and lacks fruits and vegetables in her diet. On examination and investigations she has distended neck veins, peripheral edema, and elevated lactate and pyruvate levels. Thiamine deficiency is suspected. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which enzyme activity should be tested to confirm it?

choices.text: Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD); branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase

questions.solution:
Thiamine Deficiency

  • Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.
  • Polishing grains removes the aleurone layer, reducing thiamine content.

Deficiency Manifestations

Dry Beriberi

  • More common CNS manifestations
  • Pain, paresthesia, and loss of reflexes
  • Peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbances (Option A ruled out)

Wet Beriberi

  • Cardiovascular symptoms: breathlessness, palpitations, and peripheral edema
  • Distended neck veins observed
  • High-output cardiac failure due to vasodilation (Option C)

Biochemical Parameters

  • Thiamine deficiency affects transketolase, an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Measuring erythrocyte transketolase activity is a specific diagnostic test for thiamine deficiency (Option C).
  • Earliest biochemical change: Reduced erythrocyte transketolase activity, even before clinical symptoms appear.
  • Recommended Daily Allowance: 1–1.5 mg/day

Condition-Wise Role of Thiamine and Deficiency Effects

Condition Biochemical Role of Thiamine Deficiency Manifestations
Dry Beriberi (Option A ruled out) Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function Peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, paralysis due to CNS involvement.
Wet Beriberi Thiamine is required for pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex; deficiency leads to lactic acidosis, causing vasodilation and cardiovascular symptoms Edema, palpitations, breathlessness, heart failure
Maple Syrup Urine Disease (Option B ruled out) Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids, causing convulsions, mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death
Lactic Acidosis (Option D ruled out) Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, which converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA Impaired pyruvate metabolism, leading to increased lactate and pyruvate, causing lactic acidosis

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with positive ANA > 1:80 report presents with SOB and scanty frothy urine for the past 1 week. Vitals: BP 180/120 mmHg, HR 88/min. Urinalysis reveals 3+ protein, RBC casts, and granular casts. 24-hour urine protein is 2.8 g/day. Serum creatinine is 4.8 mg/dL. The following appearance of hands is noted along with HRCT chest First differential diagnosis is
questions.solution: Hand appearance shows loss of skin creases in IP joints. HRCT chest shows pulmonary fibrosis. Kidney function is deranged with severe hypertension. All of these point to Scleroderma. SLE does not have this hand skin changes and pulmonary fibrosis. Option D has mechanic hands.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old lactating woman presents with a rapidly progressing, painful, and warm swelling involving her entire left breast. She was diagnosed with inflammatory breast cancer. Which of the following statements are correct regarding her condition?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Can be mistaken for acute mastitis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All are true

 

Explanation:

Inflammatory breast cancer:

 

Characteristic

Details

Nature
  • Most aggressive
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Worst prognosis
  • Short duration
  • Rapidly metastasizes to chest wall, bone, and lungs
  • Always stage III B carcinoma (T4d)
  • Common in lactating women or pregnancy

Differential Diagnosis

Acute mastitis (total count is increased in acute mastitis and normal in inflammatory breast cancer)

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient was brought to the ER with a history of RTA and sustained multiple injuries. On primary assessment, he was disoriented and complained of  severe headache. Meningeal signs are noted. On neuroimaging the following image was seen. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Subarachnoid haemorrhage

 

Explanation:

CT brain shows hyperdensities in bilateral sylvian cisterns and the basal cisterns producing star of death appearance. The combination of CT findings and headache with nuchal rigidity implies subarachnoid hemorrhage. Most common cause of SAH is trauma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of persistent cough and unintentional weight loss. The physician suspects a TB infection and performs a tuberculin skin test. Which of the following is not an example of the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this test?

choices.text: Contact dermatitis from poison ivy exposure.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Reactive arthritis.

Explanation:

The tuberculin skin test (TST) mentioned in the scenario represents Delayed type hypersensitivity (Type IV hypersensitivity).
Reactive arthritis, on the other hand, shows Type III hypersensitivity.

Examples of Type IV hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Contact dermatitis from exposure to
    • Urushiol from poison ivy or poison oak
    • Detergent
    • Artificial jewellery (Ni and Cd)
  • Granuloma
  • Mantoux test
  • Lepromin test
  • Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn’s disease)
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Type IV > Type III hypersensitivity)
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: An 18 year old girl comes to the OPD with complaints of irregular cycles, weight gain and excessive hair growth on the face. You are suspecting PCOS. What will be the initial management for hirsutism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) OCPs with cyproterone acetate

 

Explanation :

Acne and Hirsutism treatment in PCOS

OCPs with Anti Androgens (fourth generation combined pills are preferred)

  • Oral combined pills with cyproterone acetate (DOC)
  • Oral combined pills with spironolactone

 

Lifestyle changes

  • Weight loss eg. more than 5% of previous weight alone
  • Cigarette smoking stopped

questions.text: A 10-week-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The mother reports that the baby received the first dose of Hepatitis B at birth but missed the scheduled vaccinations at 6 weeks. questions.text:
A 13-year-old female presents to the OPD due to abdominal pain and blood in stools. On examination, she had pigmented macules on her lips and oral mucosa. Endoscopy reveals multiple large, pedunculated polyps in the small intestine which shows an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?




	Autosomal dominant disorder
	Polyps are more common in the colon
	Increased risk of developing colon, pancreatic, and breast cancers
	Gain-of-function mutation in STK11 gene
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : B) 2 and 4

Explanation: The given clinical scenario and histological findings point towards the diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome :

  • Autosomal dominant disorder. (statement 1)
  • Caused by a loss of function mutation in the STK11 gene (statement 4)
  • Presents around 11 years of age.
  • Characterized by:
    • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps especially in the small intestine (statement 2)
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).
  • Polyps are large, pedunculated, and lobulated.
  • Histology - an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium.
  • Significantly increased cancer risk (statement 3)
    • Gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, breasts, gonads, and uterus.
    • Lifetime cancer risk estimated at 40%

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of sadness and loss of interest in activities, along with recent episodes of hallucinations lasting 1-2 weeks. Her mood remains low between these episodes. Which of the following statements in this scenario is/are true?

 

Statement 1: Monotherapy with tricyclic antidepressants (TCA) is effective.

Statement 2: A combination of antidepressants and antipsychotics is the treatment of choice.

Statement 3: Patient likely to have schizoaffective disorder since she experiences both mood and psychotic symptoms.

Statement 4: Electroconvulsive therapy is the treatment of choice with severe psychotic symptoms and high suicide risk.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 and 4

Explanation:

The clinical scenario here points to major depressive disorder with psychotic symptoms. The two preferred choices of treatment are the combination of antidepressants and antipsychotics, and electroconvulsive therapy (with high remission rates of up to 95%).

Patients with Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features experience psychotic symptoms only during mood episodes. In contrast, schizoaffective disorder requires at least 2 weeks of only psychotic symptoms (delusions and hallucinations) without mood symptoms (Statements 3 ruled out).

 

Definition

Major depression disorder (MDD) with psychotic features includes mood disturbance with delusions, hallucinations, or both.

Prevalence

Occurs in approximately 18.5% of MDD patients and increases with age.

Characteristics
  • Higher treatment resistance
  • More suicide attempts
  • Longer illness duration
  • Greater functional impairment
  • Higher relapse rates

Geriatric Considerations

Patients often show significant cognitive dysfunction; depressive pseudodementia may develop.

Cognitive Impairment

Combination therapy: antidepressants + antipsychotics or ECT is the standard of care.

Treatment Approaches

Monotherapy with SSRIs or TCAs is less effective. (Statements 1 ruled out)

Efficacy of ECT
  • ECT shows high remission rates (up to 95% in psychotic depression) compared to pharmacotherapy.
  • ECT is first line treatment in case of severe psychotic symptoms and high suicide risk.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with chronic burning pain, numbness, and tingling on the right side of her body not relieved with NSAIDs. The symptoms began 2 months after she suffered a stroke. On examination, she has hyperesthesia and allodynia on the right side. The clinician suspected it to be due to lacunar infarct. What could be the likely site of infarct causing her present symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ventroposterolateral thalamus

 

Explanation:

Chronic burning pain not relieved by usual NSAIDs following a stroke is due to lacunar infarct of Ventroposterolateral Thalamus, known as Dejerine-Roussy syndrome (aka) Thalamic pain syndrome.

 

Dejerine Roussy syndrome:

Cause
  • Lacunar infarct of penetrating branches of PCA (P1 segment)

Clinical features
  • Hemianesthesia affecting one half of body (initially) [Hemisensory loss]
  • Later causing burning pain sensation (during recovery)
  • O/E: Hyperaesthesia, allodynia may be present on the affected side

Treatment
  • Carbamazepine, Gabapentin, TCAs (Tricyclic antidepressants)

 

Small vessel stroke:

Cause
  • Lacunar infarct (affecting penetrating branches) secondary to atherosclerotic occlusion/lipohyalinosis

Risk factors
  • Hypertension: Most common
  • Diabetes
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Smoking
  • Hyperlipidemia

Sites & manifestations
  • Posterior limb of internal capsule (Option B)
  • Pure motor hemiparesis
  • Genu of internal capsule (Option C)
  • Clumsy hand dysarthria lacunar syndrome (facial weakness)
  • Cortical pontocerebellar tract (Option D)
  • I/L ataxia + C/L hemiparesis
  • Ventroposterolateral thalamus (Option A)
  • Dejerine-Roussy syndrome

questions.text: What is the ideal agent of choice for sterilizing the shown instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2% Glutaraldehyde

 

Explanation:

  • Flexible endoscopes and Laryngoscopes (shown in the image) are categorized under semi-critical items in Spaulding's Classification. Aldehydes are the preferred agents for sterilization of semi-critical items.
  • Spaulding’s classification of medical devices is used to classify medical devices into three categories according to the degree of risk for infection according to their use and the subsequent level of reprocessing required to render the devices safe for reuse.

 

Risk category

Recommended method

Medical device/Equipment

1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site.

Sterilisation

  • If heat resistant: Hot air oven or autoclave
  • If heat-sensitive: Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation.

Surgical instruments, implants/prostheses, rigid endoscopes, syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter

2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk):

Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids.

High-level disinfection (HLD):

Such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.

Respiratory equipment, non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans, urine bottles

3. Non-critical (low-risk)

Items in contact with intact skin.

Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD):

Such as phenols, chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol, povidone-iodine, etc

Patient items include blood pressure cuffs, ECG electrodes, thermometer and stethoscopes.

 

Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails, food utensils, bedside tables, patient furniture and floor.


 

Aldehydes:

Examples
  • 2% Glutaraldehyde (Option A): Activated by alkalinisation
  • 0.55% Orthophthaldehyde: More stable, more active
  • Formaldehyde

Mechanism of action
  • Alkylation + DNA damage by cross linking

Uses [Semi-critical: in contact with mucous membrane]
  • Flexible endoscopes, Laryngoscope (Option A), Vaginal speculum, Anesthetic equipment.
  • Specific uses:
    • Formaldehyde: OT fumigation
    • Glutaraldehyde: Bronchoscopes and laryngoscopes
    • Orthophthaldehyde: Cystoscopes

 

Alcohols:

Examples
  • 70% Ethyl alcohol (spirit), Isopropyl alcohol, Methyl alcohol

Mechanism of action
  • Membrane damage + denaturation of bacterial proteins

Uses [Non-critical: in contact with intact skin]
  • Skin antiseptic, Thermometers, Stethoscopes
  • Methyl alcohol: Fungal spores, incubators


 

Ethylene oxide (Option B): Method of Gas sterilization, used for Heart-Lung machines, respirators.

 

35% Hydrogen peroxide (Option C): Useful in sterilization of Rigid endoscopes (Arthroscopes)

 

Isopropyl alcohol (Option D): Used in disinfection of Stethoscopes, Thermometers, skin antiseptic.

questions.text: A 24-year-old boy sustained burns in an accident. He has 20% burns and is of 60 kg. What is the total fluid requirement for a day according to the Parkland regime?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 4800 mL

 

Explanation:

 

Parkland regime:

  • Fluid requirement in 24 hours in mL = 4 X % burn X Body Weight in kg

 

Substituting the values, 4 x 20 x 60 = 4800 mL in 24 hours.

 

  • Half the volume is given in the first 8 hours, and the rest half is given in the next 16 hours
  • Commonly used
  • The maximum percentage is 50%

questions.text: A patient with a fever of 103°C and pain all over his body comes to your clinic. He recently went to a high-profile medical spa, where he was treated with oral medication for his chronic psoriasis. He was elated with the complete resolution during treatment but woke up with a fever, malaise, and pain three days ago. Skin examination is given in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pustular psoriasis

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis of the image is pustular psoriasis (a type of unstable psoriasis) characterized by the presence of multiple sterile, non-infectious pus-filled blisters on erythematous skin, forming a characteristic 'Lakes of pus' appearance. 

 

  • This condition can occur due to the abrupt cessation of systemic corticosteroids, leading to rebound flare-ups of psoriasis.
  • Since it affects the whole body, it is also called Acute generalized pustular psoriasis or Von Zumbusch psoriasis.
  • Aggravating factors:
    • Withdrawal of steroids
    • Coal tar
    • Pregnancy
    • Stress

Classification of Unstable Psoriasis:

Erythrodermic psoriasis (Option B) is another variant of unstable psoriasis that presents with erythema and scales covering more than 90% of the body surface.

Psoriasis Vulgaris (Option C) also known as plaque psoriasis, is the most common form of psoriasis. It is characterized by raised, red patches of skin covered with silvery scales.

Rupioid psoriasis (Option D) is a severe form of psoriasis characterized by the development of large, thick, adherent, and waxy scales resembling limpet shells or oyster shells.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the poison found in these seeds (image)?

choices.text: Stimulation of anterior horn cells of spinal cord
Inhibition of anterior horn cells of spinal cord
Stimulation of posterior horn of spinal cord
Inhibition of posterior horn of spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stimulation of anterior horn cells of spinal cord

 

Explanation:

The given seeds are that of Strychnos nux-vomica and the poison is Strychnine which acts by stimulating all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord

 

Strychnine:

Source

Seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica and other species of Strychnos plants found in India.

Mechanism of action

  • Stimulates all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells. Greatly increases reflex excitability by removing normal inhibition of motor cell stimulation, causing widespread uncontrolled motor activity of the spinal cord (Option A)
  • Slight stimuli like noise, light, or a breeze can cause violent generalized muscle spasms

 

Differentiating Points

Strychnine Poisoning

Tetanus

1. History

History of poisoning

History of injury

2. Onset

Sudden onset

Gradual onset

3. Convulsions/Spasms

Generalized convulsions

Lockjaw (trismus)

4. Chest Movement

Chest fixed during convulsions

Not typically fixed

5. Relaxation Between Spasms

Complete relaxation between seizures

Relaxation between spasms is never complete

6. Duration Until Fatality

Ends fatally within a few hours

Death is rare within a few hours

7. Chemical Evidence

Chemical analysis reveals the poison

No specific chemical detection

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, enlarged tonsils, and orange-colored tonsils. His lipid profile shows very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Further investigation reveals that the patient has a rare genetic condition leading to severe HDL deficiency. Given these findings, which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A)ABCA1 gene mutation

The patient presents findings most likely points towards the diagnosis of Tangier disease.

Tangier disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 (ATP-binding cassette, sub-family A, member 1) gene.

 

Pathophysiology: The ABCA1 protein is crucial for the efflux of cholesterol and phospholipids to apolipoprotein A-I (ApoA-I), forming HDL particles. Mutations in the ABCA1 gene impair this process, leading to a shortage of HDL and cholesterol accumulation in tissues such as the tonsils, liver, spleen, and peripheral nerves.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Greyish-Orange Tonsils: (Hallmark feature) Tonsils, become enlarged and acquire a greyish-orange hue due to the accumulation of cholesterol esters.

  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Due to cholesterol and phospholipid accumulation.
  • Peripheral Neuropathy: Multiple nerves can be individually affected due to cholesterol deposition in peripheral nerves, leading to peripheral neuropathy.

 

LDLR gene mutations(Option B) are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, which primarily affects low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels, not HDL levels.

 

APOE gene mutation (Option C) is associated with various lipid disorders and Alzheimer's disease. While APOE influences lipid metabolism, it does not specifically cause the severe HDL deficiency.

 

PCSK9 gene mutations (Option D) are linked to familial hypercholesterolemia, affecting LDL cholesterol levels rather than HDL. These mutations result in increased LDL and cholesterol levels and are not associated with HDL deficiency.

questions.text: Based on the graph showing potassium ion permeability during an action potential, at which point does the permeability of potassium ions reach its peak?
questions.solution:
• Point D signifies the early phase of repolarization.
  • At this stage, voltage-gated potassium channels are fully open, leading to the highest permeability to potassium ions.

  • Resting Membrane Potential (Point A on graph):
    • At rest, the neuron's membrane potential is around -70 mV.
    • K+ permeability is higher than Na+ permeability due to the presence of K+ leak channels.
    • However, the overall permeability to both ions is relatively low.
  • Depolarization Phase (Between Points A and C):
    • Voltage-gated Na+ channels open faster than K+ channels.
    • Rapid influx of Na+ ions, causing a rapid rise in membrane potential, causing a steep slope.
  • Peak of Action Potential (Point C):
    • Na+ permeability is at its maximum.
    • K+ channels are also opening at this stage but have not reached their peak.
  • Early Repolarization Phase (Point D):
    • Early phase of repolarization.
    • Voltage-gated K+ channels are fully open, resulting in the highest permeability.
    • Na+ channels are rapidly inactivated during this phase.
  • Late Repolarization and After-hyperpolarization (Points E and F):
    • K+ permeability starts to decline as the membrane potential moves towards its resting state.
    • Slow closure of K+ channels results in a period of hyperpolarization, where the membrane potential falls slightly below the resting potential (Point F).

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the treatment of neck of femur fractures according to Garden’s classification?

choices.text: Garden’s type 1 is preferably treated with conservative methods and immobilization
Garden’s type 2 fractures need internal fixation
A hip spica is used in children with Garden’s type 2 fracture
Total hip arthroplasty is done in active older adults for Garden’s type 4 fracture

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A hip spica is used in children with Garden’s type 2 fracture

 

Explanation:

A hip spica is used in children with Garden type 1 fracture for immobilization with traction in older children. Type 2 needs to be treated with internal fixation due to the high chances of displacement.

 

Treatment of neck of femur fracture is based on two factors:

  • Age of the patient
  • Garden’s classification

 

Garden’s classification

Treatment in adults

Treatment in children

Garden’s type 1

(incomplete, impacted, or abducted fracture)
  • Conservative methods (Option A)
  • Immobilization in a Thomas splint with traction
  • Internal fixation with screws (if displacement is feared)
  • Hip spica
  • Traction is applied through a pin (Moore’s pin) or wire in older adolescents

Garden’s type 2

(complete but undisplaced)

Internal fixation with cannulated screws, dynamic hip screws, proximal femoral locking plates, and cephalomedullary nails. (Option B)

Garden’s type 3

(complete & partially displaced)

  • Hemiarthroplasty (done in inactive elderly of >60years of age with comorbidities)
  • Total hip arthroplasty (done in active older patients) (Option D)
  • Internal fixation (done in young adults)

Internal fixation (using Knowle’s screw)

Garden’s type 4

(complete & fully displaced)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of mild fever and a rash. The rash began with red, flushed cheeks, as shown in the image below and has now developed into a lacy, reticular pattern on the arms and legs. The child has no significant respiratory symptoms or joint pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fifth disease

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and image depicting rash, starting with a "slapped cheek" appearance and progressing to a lacy, reticular pattern, is characteristic of the fifth disease, or erythema infectiosum, caused by parvovirus B19.

Clinical features of erythema infectiosum
  • Prodromal phase: Low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection symptoms.
  • The characteristic rash in this condition is a "slapped cheek appearance”, presenting as erythematous flushing on the face.
  • The erythematous rash spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities as a lacy or reticulated pattern.


 

 

First disease (Option A) is another name for Measles / Rubeola, an exanthematous illness caused by an RNA virus belonging to the paramyxovirus family. Here, fever occurs before the onset of rash.

Second disease (Option B) is scarlet fever, which is characterised by fever and an erythematous rash along with strawberry tongue, caused by Group A βStreptococcus.

Sixth disease (Option D) is also known as Roseola infantum or erythema subitum, in which a rash appears once the fever disappears. It is commonly caused by human herpes virus (HHV)-6 and less commonly by HHV-7 and echovirus 16.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with secondary congenital glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Angel man syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Angelman Syndrome (AS) is a rare neurogenetic disorder caused by loss of function of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15. 
  • Ophthalmic findings that can be seen in Angelman syndrome include Strabismus, Refractive errors, Oculocutaneous albinism, It is not associated with secondary glaucoma.

 

Secondary Developmental/ Congenital Glaucoma

Associated Ocular Anomalies

Associated Systemic Anomalies

Glaucoma Associated with Iridodysgenesis:

  • Aniridia  (Option A ruled out)
  • Familial Iris Hypoplasia
  • Congenital Ectropion Uvea
  • Congenital Microcornea
  • Congenital Nanophthalmos

Chromosomal Disorders:

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome)
  • Trisomy 18 (Edward’s Syndrome)
  • Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome)
  • Turner Syndrome (Option C ruled out)

Ectopia Lentis Syndromes:

  • Marfan Syndrome (Option B ruled out)
  • Weill-Marchesani Syndrome
  • Homocystinuria

Glaucoma Associated with Iridocorneal Dysgenesis:

  • Posterior Embryotoxon
  • Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome
  • Peter's Anomaly

Phakomatosis :

  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome 
  • Von Recklinghausen’s Neurofibromatosis 

Metabolic Syndromes:

  • Lowe’s Syndrome
  • Hurler’s Syndrome
  • Zellweger Syndrome

questions.text:
Match the following anticoagulants with their antidotes.

 


	
		
			
			Anticoagulants 
			
			
			Antidote
			
		
		
			
			1. Warfarin
			
			
			A. Protamine Sulfate
			
		
		
			
			2. Heparin
			
			
			B. Andexanet Alfa
			
		
		
			
			3. Dabigatran
			
			
			C. Vitamin K
			
		
		
			
			4. Apixaban
			
			
			D. Idarucizumab
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Explanation:

Anticoagulant

Antidote

Mechanism

Warfarin

Vitamin K

Vitamin K helps reverse the warfarin-induced inhibition of Vitamin K epoxide reductase, resulting in ↑ carboxylation and activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Heparin

Protamine Sulfate

It neutralises and prevents the binding of heparin and antithrombin III.

Dabigatran

Idarucizumab

It is a monoclonal antibody that binds to dabigatran and neutralises its anticoagulant activity.

Apixaban

Andexanet Alfa

It acts as a decoy receptor for apixaban, binds to apixaban, and reverses its anticoagulant effects.

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the organization of NVBDCP?

1. Multipurpose Workers (MPWs)

2. District Malaria Officer

3. Directorate General of Health Services

4. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. 1, 2, 3, and 4

Explanation:

The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is a comprehensive program under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India.

Organizational Structure of NVBDCP

1. National Level:

Directorate General of Health Services (DGHS):

  • Director General: Oversees all health programs, including NVBDCP.

2. State Level:

State Health Department:

  • State Program Officer (SPO)
  • State Surveillance Officer (SSO)

3. District Level: (District Health Department)

  • District Malaria Officer (DMO) or District Vector Borne Disease Control Officer (DVBDCO).

4. Primary Health Center (PHC) Level:

  • Medical Officer In-Charge
  • Multipurpose Workers (MPWs): Conducting field activities such as spraying insecticides and distributing LLINs.
  • ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) Workers: Engaging in community outreach, education, and basic healthcare services.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The chest pain is often severe and mimics angina but is not related to exertion. His symptoms often occur at night. Barium swallow reveals a typical finding given below. Which of the following disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diffuse esophageal spasm

 

Explanation:

 

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES)

 

Definition

Uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions of the esophagus with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry: Multiple simultaneous non-peristaltic contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg; normal LES pressure and relaxation.
 

Barium Swallow (Esophagram): "Corkscrew" or "Rosary bead" appearance.

(Option A)
 

Endoscopy: Generally normal mucosa; rule out structural abnormalities.

Management

Non-Pharmacological: Dietary Modifications (smaller, frequent meals)
 

Pharmacological:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection
 

Surgical:

  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
 

Endoscopic: Dilation (less effective)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman inquiring about long-acting contraception options is considering an IUCD. What is the primary mechanism of action of the instrument in the image?
questions.solution:
IUCDs primarily prevent fertilization by altering the uterine environment, making it unfavorable for sperm survival and reducing the likelihood of sperm reaching the egg for fertilization.

Inhibition of sperm motility (Option A) is not the primary mechanism of action of IUCDs. While IUCDs can affect sperm movement within the uterus, their main mechanism of action does not rely on inhibiting sperm motility directly.

Thickening of cervical mucus (Option C) is associated with hormonal contraceptives such as birth control pills or hormonal IUCDs (like the hormonal IUD). It does not apply to non-hormonal copper IUCDs, which do not affect cervical mucus.

Inhibition of ovulation (Option D) is the mechanism of action for hormonal contraceptives such as birth control pills or hormonal IUCDs, but it does not apply to non-hormonal copper IUCDs.

Prevention of Implantation: IUCDs modify the endometrial lining, making it less conducive to implantation, though this is a secondary mechanism.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old diabetic patient presents with a non-healing ulcer on their heel that has persisted for 4 months despite regular dressing changes and offloading. The image showing the wound is given below.



Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Chronic wound is a wound that persists beyond 4-12 weeks from its first appearance
Delay in healing most commonly occurs due to prolonged inflammatory phase
Pain is initially severe, but disappears with time due to nociceptor damage
Examples of chronic wounds include vascular ulcers, diabetic ulcers, and pressure sores

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pain is initially severe, but disappears with time due to nociceptor damage

Explanation:
Chronic wounds commonly present with sharp chronic pain which increases with time. In fact, pain is one of the factors in deciding the treatment protocol.

 

Chronic wound

Definition

Any wound which persists beyond 4-12 weeks (Option A)despite conservative treatment (dressing)

Pathophysiology
  • Wounds that fail to progress through normal stages of wound healing
  • Most commonly prolonged phase is the Inflammatory phase (Option B)
  • Formation of microbial biofilms on wound

Treatment
  • Conservative treatment- Tried first, though mostly requires aggressive treatment (surgical)
  • Surgical treatment- Debridement, control of infection and inflammation
  • Surgical treatment is done when the patient suffers from intractable pain

Examples
  • Vascular ulcers (Option D)
  • Diabetic ulcers
  • Pressure sores

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent cough and fever for the past month. He has a history of working in construction and has been exposed to soil and bird droppings. A bronchoalveolar lavage is performed, and microbial elements are observed under the microscope. His urine antigen test for the causative agent is positive and a histopathological image is shown as below. Which of the following structures is most likely observed?

choices.text: Chitin and glucan in the cell wall

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chitin and glucan in the cell wall

 

Explanation:

  • This is a case of Histoplasma capsulatum infection which is a fungus and fungi have cell walls composed of chitin and glucans.
    • The patient has a history of working in construction and being exposed to soil and bird droppings.
    • His symptoms, including a persistent cough and fever, align with pulmonary histoplasmosis.
    • Histoplasma can be detected by urine antigen test.
    • Histopathological examination shows a Giemsa-stained tissue smear with macrophages containing phagocytosed yeast forms of the fungus.

Giemsa-stained tissue smear shows a macrophage with phagocytosed H. capsulatum yeast forms.

 

 

Property

Fungi

Bacteria

Cell Structure

Eukaryote

Prokaryote

Cell Wall Composition

Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans

Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid

(Options A, C, and D)

Cytoplasmic Membrane

Sterols are present except in Pneumocystis carinii

Sterols are absent except in Mycoplasma

Cytoplasmic Contents

Membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, ER)

Membrane-bound organelles absent

Nucleus

True nucleus with nuclear membrane; paired chromosomes

No nucleus or nuclear membrane; single circular dsDNA chromosome

Diameter

5 – 10 μm; may be > 100 μm

< 2 μm

Morphology

Yeast: ovoid, round; Moulds: filamentous

Cocci, bacilli, some branching

Spores

Both asexual and sexual for reproduction

Asexual (endospores) primarily for survival

 

Clinical implications:

  • Beta 1,3 glucan Antigenin serum for invasive fungal infections except Cryptococcus and Mucor/Rhizopus
  • Galactomannan test for invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus managed on metformin presents to the clinic with increased blood glucose levels. Routine investigations revealed haemoglobin of 11 g/dL, serum creatinine of 2.3, and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 30 mL/min/1.73 m2. Which of the following additional medications can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Linagliptin

 

Explanation:

  • This patient should be started on linagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor that requires no dosage adjustment for renal impairment in this patient with type-2 diabetes and end-stage kidney disease (eGFR = 30 mL/min/1.73 m2).

 

 

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors:

MOA
  • Increase Incretin Levels: Prevents degradation of incretin hormones (GLP-1 and GIP)
  • Enhance Insulin Secretion from the pancreas in response to meals. (no risk of hypoglycemia)
  • Reduce Glucagon Secretion
  • Maintain neutral weight

Uses
  • Oral hypoglycemic drug (type-2 diabetes)

Drugs
  1. Linagliptin: Safe in renal failure
  2. Teneligliptin: Safe in renal failure
  3. Vildagliptin: Hepatotoxic
  4. Alogliptin
  5. Sitagliptin
  6. Saxagliptin: (Option B)
    1. Metabolised by CYP3A4, it has more drug interactions.
    2. Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.
    3. Risk of congestive heart failure.

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
    • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema


 

Dapagliflozin (Option A), an SGLT-2 inhibitor, is not recommended for use to improve glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus whose eGFR is less than 45 mL/min/1.73 m2.

 

Exenatide (Option C), a GLP-1 analogue, is avoided in patients with end-stage renal disease or ischemic renal failure due to hypovolemia.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a neonate who was brought in with a complaint of frothiness from the mouth and respiratory distress, as shown in the provided X-ray image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula:

  • The patient’s presentation with frothiness from the mouth, respiratory distress and coiled tube in the upper esophagus shown in the X-ray is suggestive of Esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula
  • Esophageal atresia is a birth defect in which part of a baby's esophagus does not develop properly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Transient tachypnea of the newborn:

  • It is a benign, self-limited condition that can present in infants of any gestational age shortly after birth.
  • X-Ray shows normally inflated or hyperinflated lungs with streaky perihilar markings, giving the appearance of a shaggy heart border while the periphery of the lungs is clear.

Option B - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

  • It is a condition resulting from a developmental defect in the diaphragm leading to protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.
  • X-Ray shows the left hemithorax is filled with cyst like structures (loops of bowel), the mediastinum is shifted to the right, and the abdomen is relatively devoid of gas.

Option D - Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome:

  • It is more common in premature babies.
  • It usually develops within the first 24 hours after birth.
  • X-Ray shows hypoaeration, bilateral fine granular opacities in the pulmonary parenchyma, and peripherally extending air bronchograms.

questions.text: A 13 year old male patient presented with complaints of poor scholastic performance, history of recurrent seizures since infancy and the following incidental finding on his back. What does the incidental finding denote and probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) Shagreen patch and Tuberous sclerosis

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of an adolescent male patient with complaints of poor scholastic performance (low IQ), history of recurrent seizures since infancy and clinical image showing shagreen patch suggests diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis. Adenoma sebaceium is seen on face and is ruled out. Cafe au lait macules would be light brown in color and seen in NF-1 where small potato like growth would be seen. 
 

Tuberous sclerosis (BOURNEVILLE DISEASE)

Pathophysiology

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • Genes involved are TSC1 in chromosome 9 producing hamartin protein and TSC2 is on chromosome 16 producing tuberin protein.
  • Both these proteins play a role in cell growth and cell division. Mutations lead to aberrant activation of mTOR pathway signalling giving rise to various tumours.

Clinical features

  • Classical triad of seizures (epilepsy), low IQ, facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)- EPILOIA
  • Other skin manifestations include shagreen patches, hypomelanotic macules (Ash leaf macules), periungual fibromas (Koenen tumours)
  • Associated with renal angiomyolipomas, cardiac rhabdomyomas (in children)
  • Increased risk of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs)

Treatment

  • Anticonvulsants for seizures
  • mTOR inhibitors (sirolimus or everolimus) for SEGAs and seizure reduction

 

Adenoma sebaceum and Tuberous sclerosis (Option B): It is incorrect since the image shows a shagreen patch and not adenoma sebaceum.

 

Neurofibroma and Neurofibromatosis (Options A) and Cafe-au-lait spots and Neurofibromatosis (Option D):

  • Neurofibromas and cafe-au-lait spots are associated with neurofibromatosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided chest pain, which started 5 hours ago, radiating to the left arm and doesn’t get relieved on taking rest. An ECG is taken immediately which is given below. Which of the following is the drug for definitive management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reteplase

 

Explanation:

  • The above ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, which suggests ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI - inferior MI in this case).
  • Reperfusion should be the definitive treatment; hence, reteplase (thrombolytic) should be ideal.
  • Management of MI:

Definitive management

Reperfusion therapy:

  • Primary percutaneous coronary intervention: If it presents within 12 hours.
 

(door to balloon time <90 minutes)

 
  • Thrombolysis: If it presents more than 12 hours or has no access to PCI within 2 hours of presentation.
 
  • Recombinant tissue plasminogen activators: alteplase, reteplase, and tenecteplase.
 

(door to needle time <30 minutes)

 

Nitroglycerin (Option A): Incorrect, as it provides symptomatic relief but does not reperfuse myocardium.

Aspirin & ticagrelor (Option C): Incorrect alone; they are adjunctive antiplatelet agents but do not restore vessel patency alone.

Morphine (Option D): Incorrect, as it only manages pain but does not affect the underlying occlusion.

questions.text: Following CT image is kept as a spotter in your final year exam viva. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Marked cell located between floor of orbit and superior boundary of maxillary sinus is known as Haller cell - an example of anterior ethmoidal air cell.

 

Ethmoidal air cells:

Anterior Air cells:

Agger Nasi
  • Anterior most air cell of Ethmoid sinus
  • Site: Within the Lacrimal bone in the medial side of the Orbit
  • Relation: Anterolateral and inferior to the frontal recess

Haller cell
  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cell
  • Site: Present between floor of orbit and upper boundary of maxillary sinus

Bulla ethmoidalis
  • Most consistent and largest ethmoid air cell
  • Located just posterior to the Agger nasi

 

Posterior Air cells:

Onodi cell
  • Also known as spheno-ethmoidal air cell
  • Close proximity to Optic nerve and Internal carotid artery
  • Better appreciable on CT- axial view

 

Concha bullosa (Option A):

  • Pneumatization of middle turbinate
  • Most common deformity seen in nose, non-pathological
  • CT:


 

Pneumatized superior turbinate (Option C):

  • Occasionally the superior turbinate can undergo pneumatization
  • CT:

questions.text: Given below is the image of a parasite. From the options pick a disease that is not transmitted by it.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Oriental sore

Explanation:

The parasite given in the image is a louse. Oriental sore is transmitted by sandflies, and lice transmit the rest.

 

Types of Lice
  • Head louse (Pediculus capitis)
  • Body louse (Pediculus corporis)
  • Pubic or crab louse (Phthirus pubis)

Transmission
  • Direct contact with infested persons.
  • Indirect contact through clothing, bedding, combs, or brushes.
  • Lice can be blown by wind from heavily infested individuals.

Diseases Transmitted
  • Epidemic typhus (caused by Rickettsia prowazekii)
  • Epidemic relapsing fever (caused by Borrelia recurrentis)
  • Trench fever (caused by Rickettsia quintana)
  • Dermatitis due to scratching and secondary infection.

Control Measures
  • Malathion
  • Personal hygiene
  • Mass delousing

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a palpable mass in her left breast. On examination, the mass is 3 cm in diameter, and there is no evidence of skin or chest wall involvement. An ultrasound reveals a single enlarged axillary lymph node. Biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma, ER/PR positive, HER2 negative, shows no distant metastasis. What is the most appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Total mastectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB)
Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) with SLNB followed by radiotherapy (RT)
BCS with axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) without radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) with SLNB followed by radiotherapy (RT)

 

Explanation:

  • The tumour is classified as T2 due to its 3 cm size, N1 because of a single enlarged axillary lymph node, and M0 as there is no distant metastasis, placing it in Stage IIB.

Management of Early Invasive Breast Cancer

Stages Involved: I, IIA and IIB

 

  • Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS): Preferred for suitable candidates to preserve breast tissue.
  • Post-Operative Radiotherapy (RT): Given after BCS to prevent recurrence.
  • Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB): Performed with BCS to assess lymph node involvement.
  • BCS + SLNB + RT is the standard approach for most early-stage invasive breast cancer cases.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of developmental delay, multiple hypopigmented macules on his trunk, and a history of infantile spasms. On examination, he also has facial angiofibroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tuberous Sclerosis

 

Explanation: The given clinical presentation suggests the diagnosis of Tuberous Sclerosis (TSC), an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome.

 

  • This syndrome is caused by mutations in the genes TSC 1(Chromosome 9) and TSC 2 (Chromosome 16), which encode the proteins hamartin and tuberin, respectively.
  • There are four pathognomic skin lesions associated with this condition:
  1. Ash-leaf macules are characterized by oval or irregularly shaped hypopigmented (lighter than surrounding skin) patches and are accentuated on Wood’s lamp examination.
  2. Angiofibroma, previously misnamed adenoma sebaceum, consists of hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands in immature hair follicles.
  3. Periungual fibroma (Koenen tumours) emerge from the nail folds.
  4. A Shagreen patch is characterized by thickened, leathery skin and typically appears as irregularly shaped plaques with a rough, raised surface, commonly located on the lower back.

 

 

 

Angiofibroma

Infantile spasms, also known as West syndrome, can occur in infants and young children with tuberous sclerosis complex. .

 

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia (Option A) manifests as progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias, immune system dysfunction predisposing to recurrent infections, high levels of alpha-fetoprotein in serum, and increased susceptibility to malignancies, particularly lymphomas and leukemias.

  • They also present with telangiectasias (small, dilated blood vessels) which are most commonly seen on the conjunctiva of the eyes but also in other parts of the skin, and photosensitivity.

 

 

 Sturge-Weber syndrome (Option B) or encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a rare congenital disorder caused by a mutation in the GNAQ gene on chromosome 9.

  • It is characterized by port-wine stain (nevus flammeus), typically involving the ophthalmic and maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, glaucoma, and leptomeningeal angiomas.

 

 Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (Option D) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by mutations in the VHL gene located on chromosome 3.

  • Clinical manifestations include central nervous system and retinal hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours, endolymphatic sac tumours, and multiple cysts in different organs.

questions.text: During Psychiatry rotations, the consultant presents a case study of a 20-year-old female patient diagnosed with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). The patient has a history of excessive handwashing, intrusive thoughts about contamination, and significant anxiety regarding the cleanliness of her environment. He emphasizes the importance of understanding common comorbidities associated with OCD, as they can impact treatment planning and patient outcomes. Which is the most common comorbid condition observed in patients with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Major Depressive Disorder

Explanation:

Major Depressive Disorder is the most common comorbidity seen in individuals with OCD. It is crucial to evaluate for depression in these patients, as the first line of treatment for patients of OCD with depression is pharmacotherapy.

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

  • Patient has recurrent obsessions and compulsions.
  • Recurrent obsessions or compulsions may cause severe distress or anxiety to the person.

 

Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

 

  • These are time-consuming (at least 1 hr/day) and significantly interfere with the person’s routine, occupational functioning, usual social activities, or relationships.
  • Patients can have only obsessions, only compulsions, or both obsessions and compulsions (most common).
  • Most common comorbidity associated with OCD is major depressive disorder (67%). (Option B)

 

  • Major symptom patterns:

Contamination / Cleansing
  • Most common presentation.
  • An obsession with contamination followed by washing and avoidance of the presumably contaminated object.

Pathological doubt /checking
  • Second most common presentation.
  • Obsession of doubt, usually followed by compulsion of checking.

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts
  • Third most common presentation.
  • Obsessed with intrusive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts without a compulsion.

Symmetry/ordering
  • Fourth most common presentation.
  • Patient needs symmetry/precision which results in the compulsion of slowness.

Other symptoms
  • Religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

 

Epidemiology:

  • Lifetime prevalence- 2 to 3%.
  • More common in females than males (Adolescents M>F).
  • Mean age of onset in OCD is 19 years, early onset is more in males.

 

Etiology:

  • OCD has been linked to the striatum, orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, and corticostriatal–thalamic–cortical (CSTC) circuit.
  • Neurotransmitters implicated are neurotransmitter systems that contribute to OCD, including serotonergic, dopaminergic, glutamatergic, and GABAergic systems.
  • Genetic susceptibility plays a role in OCD.

 

Treatment:

Pharmacotherapy:

  • First line:
    • SSRIs (preferred) and Clomipramine
    • Treatment should be continued for 1-2 years
  • Augmenting agents:
    • Antipsychotics: Risperidone, Aripiprazole.
    • Others: Memantine, riluzole, ketamine, lamotrigine, and N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Psychotherapy:

  • Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT):
    • Exposure and response prevention (ERP).
    • Exposure to feared situations is given. The patient is asked not to engage in a compulsive response.
  • Other therapies are desensitization, thought-stopping, flooding, aversive conditioning, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy.
  • In younger patients, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is preferred first.
  • In more severe symptoms or comorbid depression, pharmacotherapy is preferred first.
  • Combination of CBT and pharmacotherapy is particularly useful.

Somatic Therapies:

  • Anterior cingulotomy and capsulotomy.
  • Deep brain stimulation with implantation of electrodes.

 

Generalized Anxiety Disorder (Option A): While frequently co-occurring, GAD is not the single most common comorbidity; Major Depressive Disorder has a higher prevalence rate among OCD patients.

Panic Disorder (Option C): Panic disorder is less frequently observed as a comorbidity in OCD patients compared to Major Depressive Disorder.

Social Anxiety Disorder (Option D): While possible, social anxiety disorder is not as commonly comorbid with OCD as Major Depressive Disorder.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presents to a clinic with complaints of painless genital ulcer. He reports that the ulcers have been present for several weeks and have been progressively increasing in size. He also mentions that the ulcers bleed easily upon touch and are not indurated. A picture of the ulcer is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Donovanosis

Explanation:

The image depicts a beefy-red ulcer with a granulomatous base.

  • The presence of a painless, beefy-red ulcer with a granulomatous base that bleeds easily on touch, indicates a diagnosis of Donovanosis.

Characteristic

Description

Causative Agent

Klebsiella granulomatis bacterium

Clinical Presentation

Painless ulcers or nodules in genital, perianal, or inguinal regions; ulceration with beefy red, granular base

Progression

Slowly progressive, may lead to extensive tissue destruction if untreated

Complications

Genital deformity, lymphatic obstruction, secondary bacterial infections

Diagnostic Tests

Tissue biopsy, Wright or Giemsa staining of tissue samples, PCR for bacterial DNA

Treatment

Doxycycline (200mg daily) or azithromycin (1g once a week)for 3 weeks

 

Characteristic

Donovanosis

Syphilis (Option A)

Chancroid (Option B)

LGV (Option C)

Causative Agent

Klebsiella granulomatis bacterium

Treponema pallidum bacterium

Haemophilus ducreyi bacterium

Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1-L3)

Appearance of Ulcer

Beefy red, painless, exuberant granulation tissue

Painless, solitary, firm, round ulcer

Multiple necrotic based non indurated with undermined edges and bleeds on touch

Painless herpetiform transient ulcer

Images

questions.text: In a population of 1000 individuals, 200 develop oral cancers over a 10-year period. Among the total population, 100 are regular tobacco users, from which 60 developed oral cancers. Calculate the Population Attributable Risk (PAR) of oral cancers due to tobacco use in this population.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 22%

Explanation:

 

Tobacco user

No Tobacco

Total

Disease Present

60

140

200

Disease Absent

40

760

800

Total

100

900

1000

Calculate the overall incidence rate (Itotal) of oral cancers in the population:

Given:

  • Total population (N) = 1000
  • Cases of oral cancers (C) = 200

Total = 200/1000 = 0.2
The overall incidence rate of oral cancers in the population (Itotal) is 0.2, or 20%.

Calculate the incidence rate (Iunexposed) of oral cancers in non-tobacco users:

Given:

  • Non-tobacco users = Total population (N) - Tobacco users.
  • Cases of oral cancers among non-tobacco users = Total cases - Cases among tobacco users.

Therefore, the incidence rate of oral cancers among non-tobacco users (Iunexposed) is 0.1556 or 15.56%.

Population Attributable Risk (PAR):


PAR = (0.20.−0.1556​)/0.2

= 0.044/ 0.2

= 0.22

Population Attributable Risk (PAR) of oral cancers due to tobacco use in this population is approximately 0.22 or 22%

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of mitral valve replacement (on warfarin) and trigeminal neuralgia (on carbamazepine) has been prescribed clarithromycin for a chest infection. Her regular medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Her INR is 1.3 (target > 3 for mechanical heart valve). Which drug most likely interacted with warfarin to give this INR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carbamazepine

Explanation:

  • Carbamazepine is a strong enzyme inducer, particularly of CYP2C9 and CYP3A4, which are responsible for metabolizing warfarin.
     
  • Enzyme induction leads to increased metabolism of warfarin, resulting in reduced plasma levels and a lower INR (as seen in this case: INR 1.3).
     
  • This is dangerous in patients with mechanical heart valves who require INR > 3 to prevent thromboembolic complications.
     

Mechanism table:

Drug

Effect on Warfarin

Mechanism

Carbamazepine

↓ INR (↓ warfarin effect)

CYP inducer → ↑ warfarin metabolism

Clarithromycin

↑ INR (↑ warfarin effect)

CYP inhibitor → ↓ warfarin metabolism

Amlodipine

No significant effect

No major CYP interaction

Atorvastatin

Mild unpredictable changes

Competes with warfarin at CYP enzymes

Pharmacokinetics of Warfarin:

Parameter

Details

Absorption

Oral

Kinetics

Zero-order kinetics at high doses

Excretion

Excreted in bile, safe in renal failure

Protein Binding

99% bound to albumin

Dialysis Removal

Not dialyzable due to high protein binding

Important Drug Interactions with Warfarin:

Enzyme Inhibitors (↑ INR) – Mnemonic: SICKFACES.COM

Drug

Sodium Valproate

Isoniazid

Cimetidine

Ketoconazole

Fluconazole

Alcohol (binge)

Chloramphenicol

Erythromycin

Sulfonamides

Ciprofloxacin

Omeprazole

Metronidazole

Enzyme Inducers (↓ INR) – Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

Drug

Carbamazepine

Rifampin

Alcohol (chronic)

Phenytoin

Griseofulvin

Phenobarbital

Sulphonylureas

 

Amlodipine (Option A): Incorrect. No major effect on INR or warfarin metabolism.
 

Atorvastatin (Option B): Incorrect. May have minor interactions but not a strong inducer/inhibitor.
 

Clarithromycin (Option C): Incorrect. Would increase INR, not decrease it.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with monthly cyclic abdominal pain for the past year. She has not yet experienced menarche. The patient appears well-developed for her age, with normal secondary sexual characteristics. External genital examination reveals the following.



An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a distended vagina filled with blood, but the uterus and ovaries appear normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of cyclic abdominal pain, the absence of menarche, and the finding of a bulging, bluish hymen on physical examination are characteristics of an imperforate hymen causing cryptomenorrhea.
  • This condition leads to the accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen, which explains the distended vagina observed on ultrasound.
Cryptomenorrhea

Definition

Obstruction of menstrual blood outflow due to congenital malformations

Common Causes

Imperforate hymen, transverse vaginal septum, vaginal agenesis, cervical stenosis

Symptoms/

Complications

Primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, abdominal mass, acute urinary retention, endometriosis, iatrogenic infections

Physical Examination

Bulging hymen, abdominal mass, possible tenderness on pelvic examination

Diagnostic Tests

Pelvic ultrasound (shows collection of blood), MRI (detailed anatomy), examination under anesthesia

Treatment

Surgical intervention to remove the obstruction (hymenectomy, resection of septum)

 

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) (Option A): Here an individual with a male karyotype (46, XY) cannot respond to androgens, resulting in female external genitalia despite the presence of testes and the absence of a uterus.
 

MRKH syndrome (Option C): A congenital disorder characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina in females with normal ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics.


Asherman's syndrome (Option D) involves the formation of intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue. This condition can lead to secondary amenorrhea and infertility.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling and pain around her left ankle for the past 6 months. The pain is worse at night and unresponsive to analgesics. On examination, there is a firm, poorly defined, tender mass over the distal femur, with shiny skin and prominent veins over the swelling. The X-ray is shown below.



Which of the following is true regarding the most common site of origin for the bone tumor that the patient is having in this case?

choices.text: Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Metaphysis of long bones

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the demographics of the patient, clinical manifestation, and X-ray showing sunburst appearance, the most probable diagnosis is osteosarcoma.
  • It most commonly originates in the metaphysis of long bones.

 

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma):

  • Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin/ solid malignant bone tumor.
  • Age group: Bimodal age distribution peaking in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.
  • Gender: Males >> Female

 

Pathology:

  • Origin: It arises from mesenchymal cells.
  • Common site: From the metaphysis or meta-diaphysis. (Option C)
  • Order of frequency: Lower-end of the femur > upper-end of the tibia > upper-end of the humerus.

 

 

  • All osteosarcomas are aggressive and metastasize widely through the hematogenous route, typically to the lungs.
  • Despite its aggressiveness, it seldom penetrates the epiphyseal plate. (Option D ruled out)

 

Histopathology:

  • Anaplastic mesenchymal parenchyma with tumor cells surrounded by osteoid.

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Worsening pain and swelling, particularly night pain.
  • Pathological fracture is rare.
  • On examination:
    • Shiny skin with prominent veins over swelling.
    • Poorly defined, warm, and tender swelling.
    • Adjacent joint movement may be limited due to swelling.
    • The tumor may compress neurovascular structures, causing symptoms.
    • Usually reactive enlargement of regional lymph nodes.
  • Associated syndromes with osteosarcoma development:
    • Li–Fraumeni (p53 tumor suppressor gene mutation)
    • Hereditary retinoblastoma syndromes
    • Rothmund–Thomson syndrome


 

Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma arises from mesenchymal cells, not hematopoietic cells.
  • Hematopoietic cells are more commonly associated with multiple myeloma.

Diaphysis of long bones (Option B):

  • Ewing sarcoma commonly originates in the diaphysis of long bones, and osteosarcoma most commonly arises from the metaphysis.

questions.text: During a closed reduction procedure for a nasal septum, the surgeon selected a forceps, as depicted in the image, and asked the intern to identify it. What is the name of these forceps?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Asch’s forceps

 

Explanation:

The instrument shown in the above image is Asch’s forceps, an angulated forceps that is used in the closed reduction of the nasal septum.

 

 

 

Tilley’s forceps (Option A), also known as Tilley’s dressing forceps, have a box joint. They are used for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removing foreign bodies from the nose.


 

Walsham’s forceps (Option B) are straight and covered by rubber tubing. They are used to disimpact and reduce nasal bone fractures.

 

Hartmann’s forceps (Option C) have a screw joint, and the jaw is serrated and grooved. It is used the same as Tilley’s forceps, i.e., for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removing foreign bodies from the nose.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child visits the pediatric clinic with a high fever, cough, runny nose, and conjunctivitis. Three days later, the child develops a distinctive maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads to the rest of the body. The oral pharyngeal examination is shown below. During what period is this child most likely contagious and should be isolated to prevent transmission to others?

choices.text: 1-2 days before to 4-5 days after the appearance of rash
4-6 days before symptoms to 7 days thereafter
From 4 days before to 4 days after rash onset.
7 days before symptoms to 7 days after the appearance of the r

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) From 4 days before to 4 days after rash onset.

Explanation:

The image shows Koplik spots. The child has measles. 

Measles is communicable for 4 days before the onset of rash and 4 days after.

A period of communicability is when an infectious agent can be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected person to others, from infected animals to humans, or from infected individuals to animals or arthropods.

 

Disease

Period of communicability

Measles

4 days before to 4 days after the rash appearance (Option C)

Chickenpox

1-2 days before to 4-5 days after the appearance of rash (Option A)

Mumps

4-6 days before symptoms to 7 days thereafter (Option B)

Rubella

7 days before symptoms to 7 days after the appearance of the rash (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: Birth rate falls below death rate

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Birth Rate Falls below Death Rate:

  • In the fifth stage of the demographic cycle, birth rates decrease below death rates, leading to population decline.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Birth Rate Remains Unchanged: Birth rates remaining unchanged is not characteristic of this stage.

Option B - Death Rate Increases: Increased death rates are not expected in this stage.

Option C - Demographic Gap is Positive: The demographic gap doesn't describe birth rates falling below death rates, which is characteristic of this stage.

questions.text: Which is true regarding the health programme in the logo below?

choices.text: It provides health insurance coverage only for rural populations.
Benefits under PM-JAY are restricted to government hospitals.
PM-JAY covers up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year for hospitalisation.
The scheme primarily focuses on providing primary healthcare services.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PM-JAY covers up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year for hospitalisation.

Explanation:

PM-JAY covers up to Rs. 5,00,000 PER FAMILY per year for medical expenses related to hospitalisation, treatment, and certain follow-up care.

Features of the PM-JAY scheme:

  • PM-JAY provides health insurance coverage for both rural and urban populations across India. (Option A)
  • The scheme ensures cashless access to hospitalisation services.
  • There are no restrictions based on family size, age, or gender.
  • All pre-existing health conditions are included in the coverage.
  • The benefits can be used nationwide at all hospitals in the network. (Option B)
  • The plan covers 1685 procedures, including treatment, food, medicines, supplies, and diagnostic services.
  • PM-JAY primarily focuses on providing coverage for secondary and tertiary care hospitalisation. (Option D)
  • PM-JAY covers hospitalisation and treatment expenses and follow-up care up to three days before hospital admission and 15 days after discharge.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male undergoes an open appendectomy for acute appendicitis. The choice of incision was McBurney's incision. Postoperatively, after a few days, he presents with pain and bulging in the right lower quadrant, which is diagnosed as an indirect inguinal hernia. Which nerve injury during the appendectomy is most likely responsible for this complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ilioinguinal nerve

Explanation:
