Injury to the ilioinguinal nerve during an appendectomy, especially with McBurney's incision, is a documented complication that can lead to weakness of the inguinal canal structures. This weakness can predispose the patient to the development of an indirect inguinal hernia.

The complications associated with appendectomy are listed below:

Complication

Description

1. Wound infection

The MC postoperative complication involves infection at the surgical site.

2. Intraabdominal abscess

Collection of pus within the abdominal cavity, typically due to infection.

3. Ileus

Temporary cessation of bowel function, leading to abdominal distension and discomfort.

4. Venous thrombosis leading to embolism

Formation of blood clots in the veins, which can travel to the lungs or other parts of the body.

5. Portal pyemia (Pylephlebitis)

Infection and thrombosis of the portal vein, a rare but serious complication.

6. Adhesive intestinal obstruction

Formation of scar tissue causing bowel obstruction; MC late complication

7. Fecal fistula

Leakage from the appendiceal stump.

8. Nerve injury

Injury to the Ilioinguinal nerve and iliohypogastric nerve

questions.text: A 55-year-old alcoholic presents to the emergency department with sweating and palpitations. He is a known case of T2DM on metformin and Glipizide. Labs show plasma glucose 65 mg/dl, serum creatinine 2.0 mg/dl, BUN 70 mg/dl and serum potassium of 5.8 meq/dl. ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Send nephro call for urgent hemodialysis
IV bolus of 25% dextrose with thiamine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Send to cath lab

Explanation:

The ECG shows ST elevation in leads I, AVL, and V2-V5 & reciprocal depressions in the inferior leads (II, III, AVF). This is a case of anterior wall STEMI, and PCI should be done within 90 minutes of arrival at the hospital. After stabilisation based on eGFR value then the decision to continue or stop metformin will be made.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old male presents after a fall onto his shoulder. He complains of pain and difficulty moving the affected arm. Based on the clinical presentation and x-ray findings shown in the image, which of the following statements is true regarding the condition and its complications?




	Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus is more common than medial cord
	Malunion is the most common complication
	Subclavian vessels are at more risk of injury
	Shoulder stiffness occurs as a late complication
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Statements 2, 3, and 4 are true

 

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a left clavicular fracture, and injury to the medial cord of the brachial plexus is more commonly associated with it.

 

Complications of Clavicle Fracture:

  Complications of Clavicle Fracture
Early Complications
  • Neurovascular Injury: occurs immediately from trauma or later due to callus formation affecting the Subclavian vessels (Statement 3) and the Medial cord of the brachial plexus (ulnar nerve) (Statement 1)
Late Complications
  • Malunion: Most Common complication of clavicular fracture (Statement 2)
  • Shoulder Stiffness (Statement 4): Common in older patients
  • Non-Union: Occurs in 1–15% of cases

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of gout presents to the clinic with increased frequency of gout attacks. His daily medications include rosuvastatin, low-dose aspirin and losartan for hypertension. He has been advised to avoid certain medications that can exacerbate his gout. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aspirin

Explanation:

Aspirin affects renal handling of uric acid in two ways:

  • High doses (>3 g/day): Uricosuric effect (blocking urate reabsorption).
  • Low doses (<2 g/day): Uric acid retention (inhibiting urate secretion).

Gout triggers can include alcohol, red meat, and certain medications. 

Drugs causing gout

Drugs beneficial in gout

Mnemonic – PAINED

  • P: Pyrazinamide
  • A: Aspirin (Normal dose <2 gms)
  • I: Immunosuppressive: Cyclosporine
  • N: Niacin
  • E: Ethambutol
  • D: Diuretic like loop diuretics, thiazides

Mnemonic – FALSe

  • F: Fenofibrate
  • A: Aspirin in toxic dose >5 gm
  • L: Losartan (OPTION B)
  • Se: Statins (Pravastatin, rosuvastatin) (OPTION D)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss over the past several months. Examination reveals generalised lymphadenopathy and mild splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is not typically associated with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Di Guglielmo Disease

Explanation:

Based on the clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and HPE image, the patient's diagnosis is Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL).

  • CLL is not associated with Di Guglielmo Disease.
  • Di Guglielmo Disease, or acute erythroid leukemia, represents a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterised by the proliferation of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.

 Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) (Option A):

  • AIHA is associated with CLL, sometimes occurring independently or in Evan’s syndrome, along with immune thrombocytopenia.
  • Peripheral smear may reveal spherocytes (round, hyperchromatic RBCs).

Evan’s syndrome (Option B):

Evan’s syndrome is associated with CLL. In Evan's syndrome, RBCs, WBCs and Platelets are affected in bone marrow:

  • RBCs: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA)  (Coomb’s positive)
  • WBCs: CLL
  • Platelets: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

Richter’s syndrome (Option C):

  • Richter’s syndrome is associated with CLL and occurs when CLL transforms to small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) in the lymph nodes. The transition from SLL to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is known as Richter's syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the ED after experiencing a brief episode of syncope. He reports occasional palpitations and dizziness. His family history is significant for sudden cardiac death at a young age. An ECG of leads V1-V3 is given below. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient, given the findings?

choices.text: Prescribe a beta-blocker and advise lifestyle modifications
It is also called Broken heart syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Deploy an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

Explanation:

  • ECG shows Coved ST elevations greater than 2 mm in the right precordial leads (V1-V3).
  • Instead of SCD in the family, ICD should be deployed as early as possible

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department with melena and dizziness. Her BP is 100/ 80 mmHg, and her pulse rate is 100 bpm. Her lab investigations reveal Hb of 8 gm/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 25 mg/dL. Based on the Blatchford score, which of the following findings would most significantly increase her risk stratification score?

a. Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm of Hg

b. High blood urea nitrogen level (> 25)

c. Diagnosis of Mallory Weiss syndrome

d. Heart rate more than 100 bpm
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a, b and d

 

Explanation:

  • All the options except the diagnosis of Mallory Weiss syndrome are a component of the Blatchford scoring system.
  • The most commonly used risk stratification systems include:
    • Rockall- Bayler score
    • Blatchford score

 

Blatchford score

Rockall- Bayler score

Used for initial assessment in case of bleeds

Most useful as it is based on endoscopic findings
  • Pulse
  • Blood Urea nitrogen
  • Systolic Blood pressure
  • Haemoglobin
  • Presence of
    • Melena
    • Syncope
    • Hepatic or Cardiac dysfunction
  • Comorbid disease (cardiac, hepatic, renal, or disseminated)
  • Age (<60 years, 60-79 years, >80 years)
  • Shock
    • Systolic BP <100 mm Hg
    • Pulse rate >100 beats/min
  • Diagnosis at the time of endoscopy (Non-malignant lesions, or malignant lesions like Mallory weiss syndrome, GI malignancy)
  • Endoscopic Stigmata of recent bleed

questions.text:
A 35 y/o female presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and mild flank pain. An ultrasound reveals a cystic dilation near the lower ureter, and an IVU is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ureterocele

 

Explanation:

The given IVU shows- a smooth, rounded structure with a radiolucent halo at the ureterovesical junction, also known as the "cobra head" appearance, which is a hallmark of a ureterocele. It results from cystic dilation of the distal ureter, which can cause recurrent infections, as seen in this case.

 

  • A ureterocele is a congenital dilation of the terminal part of the ureter where it enters the bladder. It consists of layers of ureteric and bladder epithelium.
  • Cobraneck appearance on IVU is a hallmark feature where a dilated contrast-filled ureter is surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa, typically measuring less than 2 mm in diameter.

 

Ureterocele

 

 

 

 

Note: 

  • Maiden waist deformity is a term given to describe the medial deviation of both ureters. 
  • Commonly seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis or unilateral cases of retrocaval ureter.
  • The ureters take a narrow, waist-like shape, resembling the waist of a maiden, usually at the level of the lumbosacral junction.

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (Option B): While reflux can lead to recurrent UTIs, it does not present with the cobra head appearance described on imaging. 

 

Hydronephrosis (Option C): This condition results from obstruction, leading to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces. However, it does not produce the specific cobra head appearance at the ureterovesical junction.

 

Renal calculi (Option D): While stones can cause flank pain and UTIs, they appear as radiopaque densities on imaging and do not have the cobra head sign seen with a ureterocele.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with mild left arm pain, which has worsened over the past few months, particularly after a recent fall while playing. There are no signs of infection or soft tissue involvement. An X-ray shows the findings depicted in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Simple Bone Cyst

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of left arm pain and swelling, along with an X-ray showing a well-defined, unilocular lytic lesion in the metaphysis of the left humerus, without infection or soft tissue involvement, suggests a diagnosis of a simple bone cyst.

Fallen fragment sign: 

 

Features

Simple Bone Cyst (SBC)

(Option A)

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

(Option B ruled out)

Nature

Solitary, unilocular

Benign, expansile, multi-cystic

Fluid Content

Serous or sero-sanguinous

Blood-filled

Age Group

Children and adolescents

Children and teenagers

Locations

Proximal humerus, femur, tibia

Metaphysis of long bones, spine

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic; pathological fracture

Pain and swelling; possible neurological symptoms

Imaging

Well-defined, lytic lesions

Poorly defined, eroding lesions

X-ray

  

 

Brodie Abscess (Option C) involves a chronic bone abscess where the body has contained an infection, resulting in pus or jelly-like granulation tissue, surrounded by a sclerotic zone & has associated features of infection.

 

Sequestrum (Option D) is a piece of dead bone separated from living bone, often due to infection or chronic inflammation. On X-ray, it appears as a dense, irregularly shaped area within the bone, often surrounded by a zone of lucency. In cases of chronic osteomyelitis, an involucrum may form, which is new bone growth that encases the sequestrum.

.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of progressive abdominal distension and discomfort over the past few months. A pelvic examination reveals a large, irregular adnexal mass. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a complex ovarian mass with ascites, and peritoneal nodules. Additionally, there are small nodules on the diaphragm and involvement of the retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Based on the FIGO staging system for ovarian carcinoma, what is the most likely stage of her disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stage IIIC

Explanation:

Based on the clinical findings of macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis (peritoneal nodules, diaphragm nodules) and retroperitoneal lymph node involvement, the most likely FIGO stage for this patient's ovarian carcinoma is Stage IIIC.

FIGO's staging for cancer of the ovary, fallopian tube, and peritoneum:

FIGO Stage

Substage

Description

Stage I

 

Tumor confined to the ovaries or fallopian tubes.

TNM: T1‐N0‐M0

 

Stage I A

Tumor limited to one ovary or fallopian tube, capsule intact, no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface, no malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.

TNM: T1a‐N0‐M0

 

Stage I B

Tumor involves both ovaries or fallopian tubes, capsules intact, no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface, no malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.

TNM: T1b‐N0‐M0

 

Stage I C

Tumor limited to one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, with any of the following:

 

  • Stage I C1 - Surgical spill. TNM: T1c1‐N0‐M0

  • Stage I C2 - Capsule rupture before surgery or tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface. TNM: T1c2‐N0‐M0

  • Stage I C3 - Malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings. TNM: T1c3‐N0‐M0

Stage II

 

Tumor involves one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes with pelvic extension (below the pelvic brim) or primary peritoneal cancer.

TNM: T2‐N0‐M0

 

Stage IIA

Extension and/or implants on uterus and/or fallopian tubes/ovaries.

TNM: T2a‐N0‐M0

 

Stage IIB

Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues.

TNM: T2b‐N0‐M0

Stage III

 

Tumor involves one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, or primary peritoneal cancer, with cytologically or histologically confirmed spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and/or metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

TNM: T1/T2‐N1‐M0

 

Stage IIIA1

Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only (with or without microscopic peritoneal involvement beyond the pelvis).

 

 

Stage IIIA1(i)

Metastasis ≤10 mm.

TNM: T1‐N0‐M0

Stage IIIA1(ii)

Metastasis >10 mm.

TNM: T1‐N0‐M0

 

Stage IIIA2

Microscopic extrapelvic (above the pelvic brim) peritoneal involvement ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

TNM: T3a2‐N0/N1‐M0

 

Stage IIIB

Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis ≤2 cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

TNM: T3b‐N0/N1‐M0

 

Stage IIIC

Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis >2 cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes (includes extension to capsule of liver and spleen without parenchymal involvement of either organ).

TNM: T3c‐N0/N1‐M0

Stage IV

 

Distant metastasis excluding peritoneal metastases.

TNM: Any T, any N, M1

 

Stage IVA

Pleural effusion with positive cytology.

 

Stage IVB

Parenchymal metastases and metastases to extra-abdominal organs (including inguinal lymph nodes and lymph nodes outside of the abdominal cavity).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with persistent nasal congestion, difficulty breathing, and headaches. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals multiple sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, which are insensitive to touch and do not bleed. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Initiation of intranasal steroids

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical presentation is consistent with an ethmoidal polyp due to the presence of multiple sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, which are insensitive to touch and do not bleed.
  • The initial management should involve the use of intranasal steroids to manage allergic reaction, reduce inflammation and potentially shrink the polyps.

Diagnosis:

  • X-ray: This may be used but is less detailed.
  • Non-contrast CT scan: Investigation of choice for detailed imaging, more sensitive and specific.
  • Elevated Serum IgE Levels: Indicates allergy but not specific to ethmoidal polyps.
  • Saccharin Test: Assesses ciliary motility disorder.
  • Elevated Nasal Nitric Oxide Measurement: Indicates ciliary motility disorder.
  • Elevated Sweat Chloride Test: Suggests cystic fibrosis, a ciliary motility disorder.
  • Electron Microscopy: Elevated trans-epithelial electrical potential difference indicates cystic fibrosis when suspected.
  • Gene and DNA Analysis: Diagnoses genetic abnormalities, including cystic fibrosis.

 

Treatment:

  • Conservative:
    • Antihistamines: To manage allergic symptoms.
    • Steroids:
      • Systemic Steroids: For more severe cases.
      • Topical Intranasal Steroids: For localized treatment.
    • Nasal Decongestants: To reduce nasal congestion.
    • Reevaluation: After medical therapy, check if the polyps have shrunk or disappeared.
  • Surgery:
    • Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS): For removal of polyps and addressing underlying issues.
    • KTP laser used for ablation.

 

Immediate Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (Option A): Surgery is usually considered after medical management fails not as the initial step.

Conducting a Saccharin Test (Option C): This test assesses ciliary motility disorder, which is not indicated based on the presentation of nasal polyps.

Performing a Sweat Chloride Test (Option D): Not relevant as the initial management of nasal polyps.

questions.text:
Match the following Thyroid scan images with respective conditions:

 


	
		
			 
			1.
			
			
			A. Graves Disease
			
		
		
			
			 

			2.
			
			
			B. Cold nodule
			
		
		
			 
			3.
			
			
			C. Hot Nodule
			
		
		
			
			 

			4.
			
			
			D. Toxic Multinodular Goiter
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

 

Normal Thyroid: Uniform uptake

Hot Nodules (Image 1):

  • Increased uptake in specific areas
  • Often benign and indicate hyperfunctioning tissue.
  • Risk of Malignancy: 1-3%

Cold Nodules (Image 4):

  • Reduced uptake in specific areas
  • Risk of Malignancy: 17-20%

Grave’s Disease (Image 2): Increased uptake throughout the thyroid gland, showing heightened overall activity (Diffuse goiter) 

Toxic Multinodular Goiter (Image 3):

  • Multiple areas of varying uptake
  • Some nodules might show increased activity (Hot Nodules)
  • Some might show decreased activity (Cold Nodules)

Thyroiditis (Inflammation of the Thyroid): Decreased uptake throughout the areas of inflammation due to follicular destruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with trauma to his lower jaw. He needs stitches on his lower lip near the incisors. Which nerve block will provide adequate anesthesia for suturing the lower lip and nearby gingiva?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Mental nerve block


Explanation:

The mental nerve provides sensation to the lower lip, labial mucosa, and gingiva near the incisors and canines, making it the correct choice for anesthesia in this case.

 

Face blocks

 

Most of the facial region is supplied by the Trigeminal nerve and its branches.

Anatomy:

  • Cranial nerve V arises from the brainstem and forms the Gasserian (sensory) ganglion in Meckel’s cave.
  • The three nerve divisions (ophthalmic, maxillary, mandibular) exit the skull separately.

 

Nerve Block

Anatomy

Anesthesia Distribution

Technique

Supraorbital & Supratrochlear (Ophthalmic Nerve) (Option D)

Supraorbital nerve exits the supraorbital foramen on the superior surface of the orbital rim.

Supratrochlear exits medially at the orbital rim.

Anesthetizes the entire forehead up to the scalp's vertex.

Inject anesthetic subcutaneously above the eyebrow, from midline to the lateral orbit.

Infraorbital (Maxillary Nerve)

(Option A)

Exits infraorbital foramen below the optic rim near the first maxillary premolar.

Provides sensation loss to lower eyelid, medial cheek, side of nose, upper lip.

Retract mucosa, insert needle above the first premolar, and inject 3-5 ml between cheek and gingiva.

Mental(Mandibular Nerve)

(Option B)

Mental nerve exits the mental foramen, a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve.

Anesthetizes lower lip, labial mucosa, and gingiva near incisors and canines.

Retract lip, insert needle near first/second premolars, and inject 3-5 ml in the mucosal fold

Inferior Alveolar (Mandibular Nerve)

(Option C)

Arises from mandibular division of trigeminal (V3); landmarks: Mandibular sulcus, coronoid notch, pterygomandibular raphe.

Anesthetizes all lower teeth, gums, anterior labial and lingual areas.

Insert needle into pterygomandibular raphe, tap bone, withdraw slightly, and inject 2-3 ml.

Complications

  • Risks include intravascular or subarachnoid injection, Horner syndrome, and motor block of jaw muscles.
  • Maxillary nerve blocks carry a higher risk of hemorrhage.
  • Facial nerve may be unintentionally blocked during mandibular nerve blocks.

questions.text: In a pharmacology experiment, you observe that adding a competitive antagonist increases the EC50 without changing the maximum response. Adding a non-competitive antagonist decreases the maximum response without changing the EC50. Which of the following best describes the dose-response curve changes for these scenarios?

choices.text: Competitive antagonist shifts left, non-competitive antagonist shifts down.
Competitive antagonist shifts right, and non-competitive antagonist shifts down.
Competitive antagonist shifts down, and non-competitive antagonist shifts right.
Competitive antagonist shifts right, non-competitive antagonist shifts left.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Competitive antagonist shifts right, and non-competitive antagonist shifts down.

Explanation:

 

Competitive Antagonism

Non-Competitive Antagonism

Description

Competes with agonists for the same receptor site

Binds to a different site on the receptor, alters receptor function

Effect on Dose-Response Curve

Shifts to the right, no change in maximal response

Flattens the curve, reduces the maximal response

Reversibility

Reversible

Irreversible

Maximal Response

Unaffected

Reduced

Effective Concentration for 50% of population/ EC50 (Km)

Decreased

Unchanged

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis
questions.solution:
• Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis. It catalyzes the phosphorolytic cleavage of α-1,4 glycosidic bonds in glycogen, releasing glucose-1-phosphate.
  • It is regulated by phosphorylation: Activated by phosphorylase kinase and inhibited by phosphoprotein phosphatase.
  • Different isoforms exist in the liver, muscle, and brain.
  • Requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme.

Glycogenolysis

Feature Details
Definition Breakdown of glycogen to release glucose
Location Primarily in liver and muscle
Purpose Provides glucose for energy during fasting (liver) and muscle contraction (muscle)
Rate-Limiting Enzyme Glycogen phosphorylase
End Products Glucose-1-phosphate (converted to glucose-6-phosphate, then to glucose in liver)

Steps of Glycogenolysis

  1. Glycogen phosphorylase:

    • Cleaves α-1,4 glycosidic bonds and releases glucose-1-phosphate.
    • Rate-limiting enzyme, activated by phosphorylation.

  2. Debranching enzyme (Glucan transferase & α-1,6-glucosidase):

    • Transfers trisaccharide units to the main chain (glucan transferase).
    • Hydrolyzes α-1,6 glycosidic bonds to release free glucose.

  3. Phosphoglucomutase:

    • Converts glucose-1-phosphate to glucose-6-phosphate.

  4. Glucose-6-phosphatase (Liver only):

    • Converts glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, which is released into the blood.

Regulation of Glycogenolysis

Factor Effect on Glycogenolysis
Glucagon (Liver) Stimulates
Epinephrine (Muscle & Liver) Stimulates
Insulin Inhibits
AMP (Muscle) Stimulates
ATP, Glucose-6-P Inhibits
  • Glycogenolysis in muscle provides glucose-6-phosphate for glycolysis, not free glucose.
  • Glycogenolysis in liver maintains blood glucose levels during fasting.

Rate-Limiting Enzymes in Carbohydrate Metabolism

Pathway Rate-Limiting Enzyme Key Regulation
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) Activated by AMP, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate; Inhibited by ATP, citrate
Gluconeogenesis Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Activated by ATP, inhibited by AMP, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate
Glycogenesis Glycogen synthase Activated by insulin, glucose-6-phosphate; Inhibited by glucagon, epinephrine
Glycogenolysis Glycogen phosphorylase Activated by glucagon, epinephrine, AMP; Inhibited by insulin, ATP, glucose-6-phosphate
Pentose Phosphate Pathway (HMP Shunt) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) Activated by NADP⁺; Inhibited by NADPH
TCA Cycle Isocitrate dehydrogenase Activated by ADP, Ca²⁺; Inhibited by ATP, NADH

These rate-limiting enzymes regulate carbohydrate metabolism by controlling the flux of substrates through their respective pathways based on energy demands and hormonal signals.

Phosphoglucomutase (Option A): Incorrect because it converts glucose-1-phosphate to glucose-6-phosphate, which is not the rate-limiting step.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option B): Incorrect because it converts glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose in the liver but is not involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis.

Glucan transferase (Option C): Incorrect because it helps in debranching glycogen by transferring trisaccharide units but does not control the rate of glycogen breakdown.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with symptoms of fluctuating double vision and drooping eyelids that worsen through the day. On neuro-examination DTRs are normal and power of all muscle groups except ocular muscles is normal. Blood tests confirms the presence of Anti-MuSK antibody What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate high-dose corticosteroids as the first-line treatment
Recommend immediate thymectomy regardless of symptom severity
Start anticholinesterase medications and consider immunosuppressants if symptoms persist
Advise the patient to undergo regular monitoring without any treatment

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Start anticholinesterase medications and consider immunosuppressants if symptoms persist.

Anticholinesterase medications, such as pyridostigmine, are the first-line treatment for ocular myasthenia gravis, as they help improve neuromuscular transmission and alleviate muscle weakness. If symptoms continue despite initial treatment, immunosuppressants may be considered to reduce autoantibody production and improve outcomes.

Rarely, pyridostigmine may worsen symptoms (particularly if the ptosis is already severe), possibly due to excess cholinergic stimulation → increased eyelid fatigue or paradoxical neuromuscular junction desensitization.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the ED after experiencing syncope while playing basketball. He has a palpable double impulse at the apex, and an ECG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. An echocardiogram reveals asymmetric septal thickening with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Which of the following examination findings would NOT be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Palpable double impulse at the apex
Late-peaking ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border
Pulsus bisferiens on peripheral pulse examination
Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP)

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP)

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of syncope during exertion, left ventricular hypertrophy, and asymmetric septal thickening with outflow tract obstruction strongly suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), specifically hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is more typical of constrictive pericarditis rather than HOCM.

 

 

Auscultatory Findings in Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM):

Auscultatory Feature

Description

Clinical Relevance

Ejection Systolic Murmur(Option B ruled out)

Late-onset crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

Caused by turbulent blood flow through the obstructed LVOT; best heard at the left sternal border or apex.

Dynamic Changes with Maneuvers

Increased Intensity: Occurs with decreased preload (e.g., Valsalva manoeuvre, amyl nitrite).

Indicates worsening obstruction.

Decreased Intensity: Occurs with increased afterload (e.g., handgrip, inspiration).

Suggests improvement in outflow tract obstruction.

questions.text: An HIV patient with fever and chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined, and it showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, kinyoun carbol fuchsin
Kinyoun carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, kinyoun carbol fuchsin

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -  Kinyoun carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue:

  • The presentation of diarrhea in an immunocompromised individual and the image showing an acid-fast oocyst suggestive of infection by coccidian parasites like cryptosporidium, cyclospora, and isosopora.
  • The stain used is a modification of the Ziehl Neelsen staining, in which heat is not used as a mordant, instead an increased concentration of phenol in the primary stain, i.e., carbol fuschin is used as a mordant, hence known as Cold Ziehl Neelsen staining or Gabbet's stain or Kinyoun staining 
  • Procedure of Kinyoun staining:
    • Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin: This is a modified acid-fast stain that is used to stain the Cryptosporidium oocysts. It helps visualize the oocysts under the microscope.
    • Acid alcohol: Acid alcohol (5% H2SO4 and 95% ethanol) is used as a decolorizing agent to remove excess stain from the sample.
    • Methylene blue: Methylene blue is a counterstain that is applied after the decolorization step. It helps in enhancing the contrast and visualization of the stained oocysts.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: In a town of 4000 people in the last month, malarial smears have been prepared for 600 people who suffered acute febrile illness episodes, among which 85 were found to be positive for vivax, 25 for ovale and 10 for falciparum malaria. What is the updated slide positivity rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 20%

Explanation:

 

Here, SPR = 120*100/600 = 20%

Slide positivity rate can be considered an index of the malarial incidence in a population. Hence, effective vector control strategies can be devised based on its rise and fall.

It can also serve as an effective tool during the malarial outbreaks.

Note: Slide falciparum rate has the same purpose mentioned above but is useful only for falciparum malaria.

questions.text: A researcher wants to know whether there is an association of CRP values with the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke. The study group was divided into quintiles and the following table is formed based on the study results. Which of the following statements is true regarding the relationship between CRP and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke?   	 		 			 			Quintile 			 			 			1 			 			 			2 			 			 			3 			 			 			4 			 			 			5 			 		 		 			 			CRP values(mg/L) 			 			 			0.1-1 			 			 			1.1-2 			 			 			2.1-3 			 			 			3.1-4 			 			 			4.1-5 			 		 		 			 			Relative risk 			 			 			1 			 			 			1.3 			 			 			1.7 			 			 			2.1 			 			 			2.8 			 		 		 			 			Study population  			  			 			 			6000 			 			 			6000 			 			 			6000 			 			 			6000 			 			 			6000 			 		 	   CRP - C-reactive protein

choices.text: CRP has no association with risk of Ml/stroke
Increase in CRP increases the risk of Ml/stroke
Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke
In quintile 1, there is no risk of Ml/stroke

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Increase in CRP increases the risk of Ml/stroke:

  • Increase in CRP increases the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke, as indicated by the table.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- CRP has no association with risk of Ml/stroke: Incorrect; data shows association between CRP and risk of myocardial infarction/stroke.

Option C- Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke: Incorrect; data demonstrates increasing risk of myocardial infarction/stroke with higher CRP values.

Option D- In quintile 1, there is no risk of Ml/stroke: Incorrect; relative risk of myocardial infarction/stroke in quintile 1 serves as reference point, but does not imply absence of risk.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with suspected poisoning after ingesting an unknown substance. A toxicological analysis is performed, and the following specimens are collected: blood, urine, gastric contents, and liver tissue. Which of the following specimens is most crucial for detecting heavy metal poisoning analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hair

Explanation:

Hair accumulates heavy metals over time, making it valuable for detecting such poisoning.

Toxicological Analysis in Suspected Poisoning Cases

Toxicological analysis is essential for confirming or excluding poisoning as a cause of illness or death. It involves various specimens, tests, and result interpretations.

Specimens for Analysis

Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination. (Option A ruled out)

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, fluoride/oxalate, if alcohol is

suspected

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons. (Option B ruled out)

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

suspected

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine. (Option D ruled out)

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns. (Option C)

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

Types of Toxicological Tests

Test Type

Description

Qualitative Tests

Determine presence/absence of specific drugs or toxins; positive indicates presence, negative suggests absence or low concentration.

Quantitative Tests

Measure specific concentration of drugs or toxins; crucial for assessing severity of toxicity for substances like acetaminophen, alcohols, barbiturates, and heavy metals.

Interpretation of Results

  • Negative Results: A negative result does not exclude poisoning; it may indicate the substance was undetectable or below detection limits. Retesting may yield a positive result.
  • Quantitative Analysis: Interpretation depends on ingestion timing, individual metabolism, and possible drug interactions.

questions.text: What is the main focus of the Pradhan Mantri Poshan Scheme launched by the Government of India?

choices.text: Empowering women through nutrition development programs
Providing financial assistance for rural agricultural development

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Improving nutritional outcomes among children

Explanation:

Pradhan mantri Poshan Sheme

  • Formerly known as mid-day meal scheme
  • Under the ministry of education
  • Aims to prevent school dropouts and provide nutrition for children
  • Rolled out in government schools
  • For preschoolers up till class 8
  • Primary- 450 kcal, 12 gm protein
  • Upper primary- 700 kcal, 20 gm protein

POSHAN Abhiyan:

  • PM's Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment
  • Also known as the National Nutrition Mission
  • Launched in 2018 by the Ministry of Women & Child Development.

Targets:

  • Reduce low birth weight (<2.5 kg) by 2% annually.
  • Decrease stunting (chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually.
  • Lower underweight (acute on chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually.
  • Reduce anemia by 3% annually.

questions.text: Identify the type of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autosomal Dominant Inheritance:

  • In autosomal dominant inheritance, a single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the trait or disorder.
  • The trait or disorder will be present in every generation, as affected individuals pass the mutated gene to their offspring.
  • Individuals with one affected parent have a 50% chance of inheriting the trait.
  • For example, if a parent has a dominant genetic disorder like Huntington's disease, there's a 50% chance their child will inherit the disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Autosomal Recessive Inheritance:

  • In autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are required to manifest the trait or disorder.
  • Carriers of a single mutated gene are usually healthy but can pass on the mutation to their offspring.
  • The trait or disorder might skip generations if carriers do not have affected children.
  • When two carriers have a child, there's a 25% chance the child will have the disorder, a 50% chance of being a carrier, and a 25% chance of having neither the disorder nor being a carrier.
  • An example is cystic fibrosis.

Option C - X-Linked Dominant Inheritance:

  • X-linked dominant inheritance involves a mutated gene on the X chromosome.
  • A single copy of the mutated gene on one of the X chromosomes is sufficient to cause the trait or disorder in females (since they have two X chromosomes) and in males (who have one X chromosome).
  • Affected fathers pass the disorder to all their daughters, but not to their sons.
  • Affected mothers have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to both sons and daughters.
  • An example is Rett syndrome.

Option D - X-Linked Recessive Inheritance:

  • X-linked recessive inheritance also involves a mutated gene on the X chromosome.
  • Males are more commonly affected because they have only one X chromosome.
  • Carrier mothers (with one normal and one mutated X chromosome) can pass the mutation to their sons (who get their X chromosome from the mother) and to half of their daughters (who inherit the mutated X chromosome).
  • Carrier fathers pass the mutated gene only to their daughters, who become carriers.
  • An example is color blindness.

questions.text:
Match the apolipoproteins with their respective functions in lipid metabolism:

 


	
		
			
			Apolipoprotein
			
			
			Function
			
		
		
			
			1) Apolipoprotein A-I
			
			
			a. Enhances lipoprotein lipase activity, facilitating triglyceride hydrolysis.
			
		
		
			
			2) Apolipoprotein B-100
			
			
			b. Involved in the transport of dietary lipids from the intestine to other tissues.
			
		
		
			
			3) Apolipoprotein C-II
			
			
			c. Helps in reverse cholesterol transport, removing excess cholesterol from tissue back to liver.
			
		
		
			
			4) Apolipoprotein E
			
			
			d. Essential for binding to LDL receptors on various tissues.
questions.solution:
Apolipoprotein

Associated Lipoproteins

Function

Apolipoprotein A-I

HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein)

Major protein component of HDL facilitates reverse cholesterol transport, removing excess cholesterol from tissues and transporting it back to the liver.

Apolipoprotein B-100

LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein)

Main apolipoprotein of LDL; essential for binding to LDL receptors on various tissues, facilitating cholesterol uptake.

Apolipoprotein B-48

Chylomicrons

Main apolipoprotein of chylomicrons; involved in the transport of dietary lipids from the intestine to other tissues.

Apolipoprotein C-II

Chylomicrons, VLDL (Very-Low-Density Lipoprotein)

Acts as a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase, enhancing triglyceride hydrolysis and aiding in lipoprotein metabolism.

Apolipoprotein C-III

VLDL, HDL

Inhibits lipoprotein lipase activity, affecting triglyceride metabolism and lipoprotein clearance.

Apolipoprotein E

Chylomicrons, VLDL, HDL

Facilitates the uptake of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins by cells through interactions with specific receptors; involved in lipid transport and metabolism.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the physician with painful ulcers and a burning sensation over his genital area. Physical examination reveals a fluid-filled vesicular lesion with a red erythematous base (image). All of the following are true regarding the drug of choice (DOC) for this condition, except?

choices.text: It is an antiviral drug that works as a nucleotide analogue, preventing viral replication.
It is applied topically, intravenously, or orally.
It should be taken with plenty of water.
It is also used to treat Ebstein Barr virus (EBV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is an antiviral drug that works as a nucleotide analogue, preventing viral replication.

Explanation:

Acyclovir is the drug of choice for treating genital herpes simplex virus presented with painful fluid-filled vesicles with a red erythematous base associated with burning and itchy sensation.

Acyclovir:

  • Uses: (Option D)
    • Herpes simplex virus-1 and 2
      • Genital herpes.
      • Mucocutaneous herpes simplex (use IV).
      • Herpes labialis, Keratoconjunctivitis (use topical).
      • HSV encephalitis (use IV).
    • Varicella zoster virus (VZV).
    • Ebstein Barr virus.
  • Route: Oral, IV, topical (Option B)
  • Congeners:
    • Valaciclovir: most effective for VZV.
    • Famciclovir.
  • Resistance:
    • Associated with viral thymidine kinase mutation and AIDS.
    • Foscarnet and Cidofovir (do not require thymidine kinase activation).
  • Side effects:
    • Neurotoxicity: seizures, confusion, hallucinations.
    • Nephrotoxicity: Obstructive renal failure (crystalluria).
      • Contraindicated with cyclosporine and probenecid.
      • Administer plenty of IV fluid and water (Option C).
    • Thrombocytopenia.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman, non-obese, presents with complaints of irregular vaginal bleeding over the past two months. She reports no significant medical history except for using unopposed estrogen hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the last five years

Which condition, characterized by elevated estrogen levels alone, increases her risk of developing endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Endometrial hyperplasia

Explanation:

Endometrial hyperplasia is directly related to prolonged exposure of the endometrium to unopposed estrogen, which is a significant risk factor for developing endometrial cancer.

 

It is an overgrowth of cells in the endometrium due to excess estrogen without the balancing effects of progesterone


 

Endometrial Carcinoma

Risk factors

Protective factors

  • Age (>50 yrs)
  • Obesity
  • Estrogen exposure
  • Nulliparity
  • Tamoxifen
  • Family history
    • Lynch syndrome
    • BRCA1 & BRCA2 mutations
  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy and childbirth
  • Regular exercise
  • Healthy weight management
  • LNS-IUS


 

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (Option A) is characterized by hormonal imbalances, including elevated levels of androgens and estrogen due to anovulation.

However, the primary mechanism linking PCOS to endometrial cancer is the hormonal imbalance leading to chronic anovulation and unopposed estrogen exposure rather than high estrogen levels alone.

Hormone replacement therapy (Option B) that combines estrogen with progestin (a synthetic form of progesterone) is considered safer than estrogen alone in postmenopausal women.

Progestin counteracts the estrogen's effect on the endometrium, reducing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer compared to unopposed estrogen therapy.

Type 2 diabetes (Option C) is associated with insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia, which can increase estrogen levels by decreasing the production of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG).

The primary mechanism linking diabetes to endometrial cancer is thought to be related to obesity and insulin resistance rather than elevated estrogen levels.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old female patient came with complaints of gradual progressive diminution of vision for 2 years in both her eyes. She reports that over the last year, she noticed an improvement in her ability to read without glasses. The following finding is seen on slit lamp examination over the right eye and the left eye has similar opacity.



Choose the most appropriate course of management for this patient.

choices.text: Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months.
Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months.
Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plan for Phacoemulsification.

Explanation:

Gradual, progressive loss of vision along with improvement in near vision (referred to as “second sight”), combined with characteristic slit-lamp findings, is suggestive of Nuclear Cataract, for which phacoemulsification is the treatment of choice.

  • Management:
    • Surgical measures: Mainstay of treatment.
    • Cataract surgeries:
      • ICCE (not preferred now)
      • ECCE
      • SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
      • Phacoemulsification (most preferred)
    • Followed by IOL implantation: PC-IOL (Posterior chamber-intraocular lens) is preferred.

Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months (Option A) would not address the cataract directly and would not improve the visual acuity.

Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months (Option B): The use of topical corticosteroids after cataract surgery reduces postoperative noninfectious inflammation but it is not used as the treatment for nuclear cataract.

Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses (Option D): Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses are indicated for early-stage keratoconus with astigmatism.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with esotropia, which increases on focusing near objects. This issue has progressively worsened over the past few months, and she has difficulty with close visual tasks. A refractive error of +6.50 D has been identified. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Accommodative refractive esotropia

 

Explanation:

The above scenario is a case of accommodative reflex esotropia, which has a convergent squint with high hypermetropia.

 

Esotropia

It is an inward deviation of one eye and is the most common type of squint in children.

It is of the following types:

  • Infantile esotropia (Option D) - onset is before 6 months and mostly bilateral in presentation
  • Accommodative esotropia
    • Accommodative refractive esotropia
    • Accommodative non-refractive esotropia
    • Accommodative mixed esotropia
  • Acquired Nonaccommodative esotropia
  • Sensory esotropia
  • Consecutive esotropia

 

Accommodative esotropia

 

Accommodative Refractive Esotropia

(Option A)

Accommodative Non-refractive Esotropia

(Option B)

Accommodative Mixed Esotropia

(Option C)

Cause

High hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D)

Abnormal large AC/A (accommodative convergence/accommodation) ratio

Combination of hypermetropia and high AC/ A ratio

Treatment

Correction of hypermetropia (spectacles)


 
  • Corrected by bifocal glasses with +3 DS added for near vision
  • Miotics (Echothiophate)
  • Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession

Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession

  • Vaccine vials 3 and 4: The inner square is darker than the outer circle and hence has to be discarded

  • VVM30 (Hepatitis B Vaccine): Reaches end-point in 30 days at 37°C; used for more heat-stable vaccines.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of severe vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the left ear. An Audiogram is taken and is shown below. Which of the following structures is primarily involved in the pathophysiology of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endolymphatic sac

 

Explanation:

  • Symptoms like vertigo, tinnitus, sensorineural hearing loss, and aural fullness along with audiogram findings of sensorineural hearing loss (low frequency sensorineural hearing loss, upslopping pattern) point towards diagnosis of Ménière’s disease.
  • It is caused by the dysfunction in the endolymphatic sac, caused by overproduction or malabsorption of endolymph, leading to Endolymphatic hydrops, which is the hallmark of this disease.
  • The resulting accumulation of endolymph distends the membranous labyrinth, affecting the cochlea and vestibular system causing the classic symptoms.
  • Sequence of symptoms in Ménière’s disease: Tinnitus → Hearing loss → Vertigo (± vagal disturbances such as abdominal cramps, diarrhea, cold sweats, pallor and bradycardia)

Structures Involved in Ménière's Disease:

 

Structure

Role in Ménière's Disease

Endolymphatic sac

Dysfunction causes defective absorption of endolymph, leading to endolymphatic hydrops, which results in vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and aural fullness.

Cochlear duct (scala media)

Distension of the cochlear duct affects hearing, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. It is the primary site affected in the auditory portion of the inner ear.

Saccule

Distended saccule may press against the stapes footplate, potentially contributing to vestibular symptoms and vertigo in the advanced stages of the disease. (Option C)

Semicircular canals

Secondary involvement causes vestibular symptoms such as vertigo, but they are not the primary site of the pathology in Ménière’s disease. (Option A)

Reissner membrane

In severe cases, the bulging of this membrane can result in herniation into the scala vestibuli, worsening the symptoms of vertigo and hearing loss. (Option D)

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease and started on drugs for the same 6 months ago. She now presents for a review with complaints of skin discolouration, as shown in the image below. Which of the following antiparkinson agents would have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amantadine

Explanation:

  • The skin discolouration given above, with a history of treatment for Parkinsonism, is suggestive of livedo reticularis, which can occur as a side effect of using amantadine.
  • Livedo reticularis occurs due to the release of catecholamines, which result in peripheral vasoconstriction.

Other side effects of Amantadine:

  • Insomnia.
  • Restlessness.
  • Confusion.
  • Nightmares.
  • Anticholinergic effects.
  • Hallucinations (rare).
  • Ankle oedema.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, dizziness, and shoulder tip pain. She has a history of amenorrhea for the past 7 weeks and a positive pregnancy test. On physical examination, she is pale, with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. Which of the following diagnostic findings is most indicative of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: The presence of a gestational sac in the uterine cavity on ultrasound
Free fluid in the abdomen on ultrasound
Absence of adnexal mass on pelvic exam

questions.solution:
Correct option: C) Free fluid in the abdomen on ultrasound

Explanation:
Free fluid in the abdomen on ultrasound is a key diagnostic finding indicative of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, often representing blood from the rupture.

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Blood examination should be done as a routine for:
    • Haemoglobin
    • ABO and Rh grouping
    • Total white cell count and differential count
    • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  • Estimation of β-hCG: The suspicious find­ings are:
    • Lower concentration of β-hCG compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy
    • Plasma concentration does not double in 48 hours like in normal pregnancy
  • Sonography (TVS): The diagnostic features are:
    • Absence of intrauterine pregnancy with a positive pregnancy test.
    • Fluid (echogenic) in the pouch of Douglas.
    • Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary (Blob sign).
    • Rarely cardiac motion may be seen in an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.
  • Combination of quantitative β-hCG values and sonog­raphy: TVS provides visualization of a well-formed intrauterine gestational sac as early as 4–5 weeks from the last menstrual period. The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.So if the beta-hCG level is≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.
  • Laparoscopy offers benefits in cases of confusion with other pelvic lesions.
  • Dilatation and curettage: Identification of decidua without villi structure is suggestive.
  • Serum progesterone: A level greater than 25 ng/mL is suggestive of viable intrauterine pregnancy whereas a level less than 5 ng/mL suggests an ectopic or abnormal intrauterine pregnancy.
  • Laparotomy offers benefits when in doubt.

Elevated serum hCG (Option A) levels and the presence of a gestational sac (Option B) in the uterine cavity are not specific to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.


Absence of adnexal mass on the pelvic exam (Option D): The absence of an adnexal mass on the pelvic exam does not rule out an ectopic pregnancy, especially if a rupture has occurred.

questions.text:
Match the Following Murmurs to their characteristics


	
		
			
			Murmurs
			
			
			Characteristics 
			
		
		
			
			1. Mitral Stenosis
			
			
			A. High-pitched, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border.
			
		
		
			
			2. Aortic Stenosis
			
			
			B. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, often with a displaced apical impulse.
			
		
		
			
			3. Patent Ductus Arteriosus
			
			
			C. Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard along the left sternal border.
			
		
		
			
			4. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
			
			
			D. "Machine-like" continuous murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular area.
			
		
		
			
			5. Mitral Regurgitation
			
			
			E. Loud S1, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.
			
		
		
			
			6. Aortic Regurgitation
			
			
			F. Systolic ejection murmur, often with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern, best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 - E, 2 - F, 3 - D, 4 - A, 5 - B, 6 - C

Explanation: 

Mitral Stenosis

Low-pitched diastolic murmur with opening snap, best at the apex. Accentuated by exercise or Valsalva's maneuver. 

Aortic Stenosis

Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids

Patent Ductus Arteriosus

A continuous, machine-like murmur, heard at the left infraclavicular area

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

Harsh systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern

Mitral Regurgitation

Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla

Aortic Regurgitation

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left sternal border

Graham Steell Murmur

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation, heard best at the left upper sternal border.

Austin Flint Murmur

Low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur due to severe aortic regurgitation causing turbulent flow in the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is found dead in his apartment with no signs of external trauma. Based on the provided image of the eye showing hazy corneas and sunken eyeballs, what is the most likely time since death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3 - 4 hours

 

Explanation:

The image shows tache noire that forms after 3-4 hours, indicating that this case fits within that time frame. Corneal haziness usually develops within 2 hours, and sunken eyeballs develop within minutes. These findings support an estimated time of death around 3-4 hours ago.

 

Postmortem Changes in Eye:

  • Medicolegal Importance: Changes in the retina and vitreous humor are more significant for estimating the time since death.

Part of Eye

Features

Time Since Death (TSD)

Retina

  • Kevorkian Sign: Fragmentation or segmentation of blood column in retinal vessels (cattle trucking or shunting)
  • Occurs within minutes and lasts about an hour.
  • Seen using an opthalmoscope.

Few minutes

Vitreous Humor
  • Vitreous humor’s accessibility and resistance to putrefaction make it ideal for forensic analysis.
  • Potassium along with hypoxanthine increases due to autolysis of choroid and retinal cells.
  • Potassium levels provide accurate TSD estimates, unaffected by external factors.
  • The Sturner and Gantner formula is used to estimate TSD from potassium levels.

-

Sclera

  • Tache Noire: Appears as two yellow triangles on the sclera (base on limbus, apex at medial or lateral canthus), which darken to brown and then black.
  • Caused by desiccation and deposition of cellular debris, mucus, and dust on exposed conjunctiva and the sclera underneath.
  • Forms if eyelids remain open for 3-4 hours postmortem.

3 - 4 hours

Cornea

  • Cornea becomes hazy within 2 hours of death due to drying and dust deposition.
  • Delayed for about 2 hours if lids are closed after death.
  • Transient haziness can be removed by applying water, but permanent opacity occurs after 10-12 hours due to decomposition.

Within 2 hours

Eyeball

  • Eyes appear sunken and become softer within minutes due to reduced intraocular tension.
  • Intraocular pressure drops from 10-22 mmHg during life to zero within 2 hours.

Within 2 hours (IOP becomes zero)

questions.text: A 23-year-old pianist comes to the clinic complaining of weakness in her fingers. She says she is unable to play a challenging piece in a song. Which of the following is the innervation ratio of the group of muscles affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1:3

Explanation: This patient cannot play the piano, which suggests that the small muscles of the hands are affected.

  • The innervation ratio refers to the number of muscle fibres controlled by a single motor neuron.
  • The innervation ratio of small-sized motor units is 1:3 to 1:6.

 

 

Difference between Small size motor unit vs Large size motor unit:

Aspects

Small-sized motor unit

Large-sized motor unit

Required for

Fine movements.

Gross movements.

Present in

Extraocular muscles (EOM) and the small muscles of our fingers.

Lower limb muscles, particularly the leg muscles, i.e., gastrocnemius and back muscles.

Innervation ratio

1:3 to 6, i.e. one single axon supplies 3-6 skeletal muscle fibres. (Option D)

1:600 to 2000, i.e., one single axon supplies 600 - 2000 skeletal muscle fibres. (Option A, B, C)

questions.text: A 4 year old boy is brought to the clinic because his parents have noticed a significant regression in his abilities over the past year. He previously spoke in full sentences, engaged in social play, and was potty trained but has now lost these skills. He exhibits behaviours resembling those seen in autism. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Heller's Syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Heller's Syndrome is characterised by marked regression in multiple areas of development after at least two years of normal development, typically between the ages of 3 and 4.

 

Heller's Syndrome: Also known as childhood disintegrative disorder or disintegrative psychosis classified under Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) in DSM-5.

 

Characteristics:

  • Marked regression in multiple developmental areas after at least two years of normal development.
  • It typically occurs between 3 and 4 years of age.

Affected Developmental Domains:

Domain

Description

Language skills

Significant loss of previously acquired language abilities

Social responsiveness

Deterioration in social interactions

Play

Loss of interest or ability to engage in play

Motor skills

Regression in gross and fine motor skills

Bladder and bowel control

Loss of previously established control
  • After regression, children closely resemble those with autistic disorder.

Asperger's Syndrome:

  • No longer a separate diagnosis in DSM-5; now classified under ASD.
  • Characterised by:
    • Impaired social relatedness.
    • Repetitive and stereotyped behaviours.
    • No significant language delays or abnormalities.
    • Cognitive development is normal.

Asperger's Syndrome (Option A) does not typically involve regression of skills, as it is a form of autism without significant delays in language or cognitive development.

Tourette Syndrome (Option C): This condition involves the presence of motor and vocal tics and does not involve regression of previously acquired developmental skills.

Rett syndrome (Option D) primarily affects girls and usually presents with stereotypical hand-wringing and loss of motor function, not seen in this case.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain and tenderness after sustaining an injury from a fall. An X-ray of the region is provided below. Considering the mechanisms of injury, what is the most common cause associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fall on the shoulder

 

Explanation:

The scenario with X-ray findings points towards a right Clavicular fracture, most commonly caused by a fall directly onto the shoulder.

 

Clavicle or Collarbone:

  • It is a long, slightly S-shaped bone located horizontally at the junction of the neck and trunk. It articulates medially with the sternum and the cartilage of the first rib and laterally with the acromion process of the scapula.
  • Structural features: It is the only long bone that lies horizontally, does not contain a medullary cavity, and remains subcutaneous along its entire length.
  • Ossification:
    • It is the first bone to begin ossifying (between the fifth and sixth week of fetal development) and the last to finish ossification (around 25 years of age).
    • It is the only long bone that ossifies from two primary centers.
    • It primarily ossifies in the membrane, except for its medial end, which ossifies in cartilage (unlike other long bones).

 

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Fall on the shoulder: The most common mechanism is a fall directly onto the point of the shoulder, accounting for 91% of cases.

Direct injury (Option A):
Incorrect because direct trauma (such as a blow or impact over the clavicle) is a less common mechanism than indirect force from a shoulder fall.

Fall onto an outstretched hand (Option B):
Incorrect because this mechanism typically causes scaphoid fractures, distal radius fractures, or shoulder dislocations, not clavicle fractures.

Fall from a height (Option D):
Incorrect because while it can result in clavicle fractures, it is not the most common cause. It usually leads to multiple injuries, and the clavicle is not selectively involved unless the person lands on their shoulder.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct function of the shown image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • The given image is of the Swan-Ganz catheter.
  • These catheters monitor intracardiac pressures, and cardiac output, provide infusing solutions, and measure temperature.

Temperature Monitoring in General Anesthesia

  • Importance: Essential for detecting malignant hyperthermia and quantifying hyperthermia/hypothermia.
  • Common Disturbance: Inadvertent hypothermia is the most prevalent thermal issue during surgery.
  • Thermoregulatory Control: General anesthetics significantly impair the body's ability to regulate temperature.
  • Core Temperature Measurement: Always monitor core temperature during anesthesia.

Preferred Measurement Sites:

  • Pulmonary Artery (Best site)
    • Monitored via Swan-Ganz catheter.

  • Tympanic Membrane
  • Oesophagus
  • Nasopharynx

Monitoring Requirements

  • Major Surgeries: Core temperature monitoring is essential during major surgical procedures.

questions.text: A 34 y/o G2P1 woman comes at 39 wks gestation and her blood sugar levels are well controlled on insulin. Induction of labor is planned for her. Which of the following is wrong statement regarding her management?

choices.text: If sugar levels <70 mg/dl give 5%dextrose at 100-150 ml/hr
If sugar levels >100 mg/dl give insulin at 1 - 1.25 units/hr
Give morning dose of insulin on day of induction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Give morning dose of insulin on day of induction

Explanation:

Morning dose of insulin is omitted on the day of induction.

Important points to remember on management of GDM mother during induction of labor:

  • Evening dose of insulin before the day of induction is administered.
  • The morning dose of insulin is omitted on the day of induction.
  • Start normal saline (NS) at 100 - 125 ml/hr (Option A).
  • If blood sugar levels <70 mg/dl give 5%dextrose at 100-150 ml/hr (Option B).
  • If blood sugar levels >100 mg/dl give insulin at 1 - 1.25 units/hr (Option C).
  • Ideally blood sugar levels maintained between 70-100 mg/dl.
  • Hourly monitoring of blood glucose is done.

​​

			c.

			3. Debakey II
			 
		
		
			 
			4. Debakey III
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) A:2, B:1, C:4

Explanation:

Aortic aneurysms are divided into various types with respect to Stanford and DeBakey classification as follows:

  1. DeBakey Classification
  2. Stanford Classification

DeBakey Classification:

Type

Origin

Extent

Type I
(Option A)

Ascending aorta

Extends into arch and descending aorta

Type II

Ascending aorta

Confined to ascending aorta

Type III
(Option C)

Descending aorta

Starts distal to left subclavian artery

IIIa

Limited to thoracic aorta

  

IIIb

Extends below diaphragm

  

 

  • Stanford Classification:

    Type

    Description

    Management Implication

    Type A
    (Option B)

    Involves the ascending aorta (± arch, descending aorta)

    Surgical emergency

    Type B

    Involves only the descending aorta, distal to the left subclavian artery

    Medical management unless complications arise

 

Relation Between Stanford and DeBakey:

  • Stanford Type A = DeBakey Type I and II
     
  • Stanford Type B = DeBakey Type III

questions.text: A healthcare provider is educating a group of expectant mothers about situations where breastfeeding might not be recommended. Which of the following maternal conditions would most likely contraindicate breastfeeding?

choices.text: History of mastitis with successful treatment during pregnancy.
Active varicella-zoster infection with lesions on the breast.
Use of a low-dose, progestin-only contraceptive pill.
Mildly elevated blood pressure controlled with medication.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Active varicella-zoster infection with lesions on the breast.

 

Explanation:

 

Breastfeeding Contraindications

Maternal Contraindications

Infectious Diseases:

  

Active Tuberculosis

Mothers with active tuberculosis should delay breastfeeding until they have completed at least two weeks of appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of transmission.

Active Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Lesions on the Breast:

Breastfeeding is contraindicated if a mother has active herpetic lesions on her breast to prevent transmission to the infant.

Varicella-Zoster Infection

If the mother has active chickenpox lesions, breastfeeding should be avoided to prevent direct contact between the lesions and the infant. The infant should also receive appropriate immunoglobulin. (Option B)

Medications and Treatments:

Chemotherapy, Radiopharmaceuticals and Certain Medications
  • Breastfeeding is usually contraindicated during maternal treatment with chemotherapy or radiopharmaceuticals due to the potential harm to the infant.
  • Specific medications, such as some anticoagulants, anti-tuberculosis drugs, and anticonvulsants, may require mothers to avoid breastfeeding.

Substance Use: Alcohol and Smoking
  • While not a strict contraindication, alcohol consumption should be limited to less than 0.5g/kg/day.
  • Cigarette smoking is strongly discouraged.

Maternal Health Conditions:

  • Severe Illness or Surgery
  • Breast Conditions
  • Maternal issues like mastitis or breast engorgement may complicate breastfeeding and require temporary cessation but are not absolute contraindications.

Fetal Contraindications

Metabolic Disorders: Galactosemia

Infants with galactosemia, a condition where they cannot process galactose, should not be breastfed. Instead, they require specialized formulas.

Anatomical Challenges: Oral or Facial Anomalies

Conditions like cleft palate that affect the infant's ability to suckle may necessitate alternative feeding methods.

Prematurity or Low Birth Weight: Support Needs

Premature or low-birth-weight infants may initially require supplemental feeding methods until they can effectively breastfeed.

 

History of mastitis with successful treatment during pregnancy (Option A): A history of mastitis, once successfully treated, does not contraindicate breastfeeding.

 

Use of a low-dose, progestin-only contraceptive pill (Option C) is not a contraindication to breastfeeding.

 

Mildly elevated blood pressure controlled with medication(Option D): Controlled mild hypertension is not a contraindication to breastfeeding, as it does not pose a risk to the infant.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation, If the HR is less than 100/min despite PPV, the following steps are followed except:

choices.text: Ensure, whether the positive pressure ventilation is given properly or not
If needed endotracheal intubation should be done.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intubation never done

Explanation:

  • In case HR is less than 100/min despite PPV, you may intubate the baby or do endotracheal intubation.
  • Ensure if the positive pressure ventilation is given properly or not by checking if the chest movement is happening with each breath given or not.(Option A)
  • Ventilation corrective steps are used in Neonatal resuscitation to ensure the baby is getting adequate oxygen, clear airway obstruction, correct inadequate breathing efforts, prevent hypoxia, and support circulatory functions. (Option B)

 

Ventilation corrective steps includes:

  • The mask should cover the mouth and nose should fit well and provide an effective seal
  • Ensure the Mask is of appropriate size
  • The head of the baby should be slightly extended and the mouth of the baby should be kept slightly open

When HR becomes less than 100/min if needed endotracheal intubation is done (Option D)

questions.text: During the procedure as given in the image, the anesthesiologist uses a 25-gauge needle to inject the local anesthetic. If the needle inadvertently penetrates too deeply and damages nearby structures, which of the following complications might arise?

choices.text: Hemorrhage from the internal jugular vein
Mandibular nerve blockade leading to loss of mastication
Damage to the facial nerve causing unilateral weakness

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Damage to the facial nerve causing unilateral weakness

 

Explanation:

The procedure shown in the image is auriculotemporal nerve block, facial nerve runs superficially in the parotid gland and innervates the muscles of facial expression. If the needle penetrates too deeply, it may damage the facial nerve which leads to U/L LMN facial paralysis/weakness.

Scalp blocks

Occipital nerve block

Greater Occipital Nerve:

  • Arises from the dorsal primary rami of the C2 and C3 spinal nerves.
  • Blocked approximately 3 cm lateral to the occipital prominence at the level of the superior nuchal line. The nerve is located medial to the occipital artery.
 

Lesser Occipital Nerve:

  • Originates from the ventral rami of the same spinal roots.
  • Blocked 2 to 3 cm more laterally along the nuchal ridge.

Zygomaticotemporal Nerve Block


 
  • Insert the needle at outer edge of supraorbital margin at a 90° angle until bone contact is made, then deposit the LA for deep injection.
  • Redirect the needle laterally to Zygomatic Arch and deposit LA along this trajectory.

Auriculotemporal Nerve Block


 
  • Given at 1 to 1.5 cm anterior to the ear at the tragus, above the temporomandibular joint.
  • Palpate the superficial temporal artery to avoid intra-arterial injection.
  • Keep the injection superficial to prevent facial nerve block.

Carotid Artery Puncture (Option A): Less likely as the procedure is performed anterior to the ear, away from the carotid artery.

 

Hemorrhage from the internal Jugular Vein (Option B): Less likely as the procedure is performed anterior to the ear, away from the internal jugular vein.

 

Mandibular Nerve Blockade Leading to Loss of Mastication (Option C): This is not a direct result of an auriculotemporal nerve block, as it primarily provides sensation rather than motor function to the muscles of mastication.

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient was admitted in the medicine ward with complaints of high grade fever, maculopapular rash and a skin lesion at the site of insect bite as shown below. He gives a recent history of hiking in a scrub forest. What is the false statement regarding the probable disease?

choices.text: Maculopapular rash involves the palms and soles
Transovarial transmission of the causative organism occurs through chiggers
The drug of choice is doxycycline

questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a 35 year old male patient with complaints of high grade fever, maculopapular rash and a black eschar at the site of insect bite with a recent history of hiking in a scrub forest is suggestive of Scrub typhus.
  • The false statement regarding scrub typhus is that the rash involves the palms and soles.(Option B)
  • Rash involving the palms and soles are typically seen in the following diseases:
    • Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii)
    • Hand-foot-mouth disease (CoxSackie A virus)
    • Secondary syphilis

 

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer. (Option A ruled out)

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in scrub vegetation i.e. low-lying trees and bushes.
  • The bite of infected trombiculid mites transmits it.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission. (Option C ruled out)
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice. (Option D ruled out)
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.
